	-	6	Added New Content	-	"""VALUES ORIENTED BUSINESS MODEL

5 minutes: Lecture

So we talked about this already a little bit, but I want to show how the different pieces of BMC fits together
Explain how the BMC fits together as a story:
Start with the right side: 
You have a product that delivers value (value proposition) to your different customer segments. If we want them to know about the product/value offered, we use different channels to reach them. Once we have reached the customer segments, we want to build relationships with them to get them coming back. Delivering value to your customers allows you to make sales and bring in revenue (maybe they even bring friends along). 
Where have you seen this before? 
This is what they did during Ignite!
You should have a clear picture of your customers, what they care about, how to reach them, and have an idea of how you will actually make money through this interaction. 

Move on to the left side:
Next let’s look at all the key activities you need to do in order to make this a reality. You need to put in work and resources to build and deliver the value you promised to your customers. There are a lot of activities and resources that go into the consistent delivery of value to your customers (running your business). You usually can’t do it all yourself. In this case, you need to find the right partners to help you achieve your tasks. These partners can help by providing resources (human, financial, etc…) or by taking responsibility for some key activities. All of this costs money to do. 

Conclusion: In the next slides, we are going to go point by point on the BMC to understand it more. We will discuss the different parts as a group and go over an example. After that, there will be time to apply it to your business. Keep in mind that this session will stay fairly high level for now. It is about getting a snapshot, not going into detail! We will go into detail during future sessions.

Transition to the next slide: We will start with the value proposition."""

	17	21	Updated Wording in Speaker Notes	"""<5 minutes: Discussion

What are key resources? How do we get them? 
Potential answers:
Key resources are the personnel, tools, and budget the team will need access to 
Every business model requires Key Resources. Your resources allow your enterprise to create and offer a Value Proposition, reach markets, maintain relationships with Customer Segments, and earn revenues. 
Different Key Resources are needed depending on the type of business model (some business need a lot of cash on hand while others need a lot of human resources)
Key resources can be owned or leased by the company or acquired from key partners (including investors).
Examples:
Physical resources (tangible assets)
Financial resources (cash), 
Intellectual resources
Human resources. 

If you are having trouble identifying the right key activities, ask yourself the following:
What Key Resources do our Value Propositions require?
Our Distribution Channels?
Customer Relationships?
Revenue Streams?

--------
More details on different common key resources. There is no need to cover them in detail. If you cover these points, you should focus on when to use these types, talk about the pros and cons of each. It shouldn’t be about explaining definitions.
--------
Types of Key Resources: Key Resources can be categorized as follows:
Physical: This category includes physical assets such as manufacturing facilities, buildings, vehicles, machines, systems, point-of-sales systems, and distribution networks. Retailers like Wal-Mart and Amazon.com rely heavily on physical resources, which are often capital-intensive. The former has an enormous global network of stores and related logistics infrastructure. The latter has an extensive IT, warehouse, and logistics infrastructure.
Intellectual Property: Intellectual property resources such as brands, proprietary knowledge, patents and copyrights, partnerships, and customer databases are increasingly important components of a strong business model. Intellectual property resources are difficult to develop but when successfully created may offer substantial value. Consumer goods companies such as Nike and Sony rely heavily on their brand as a Key Resource. Microsoft and SAP depend on software and related intellectual property developed over many years. Qualcomm, a designer and supplier of chipsets for broadband mobile devices, built its business model around patented microchip designs that earn the company substantial licensing fees.
Human: Every enterprise requires human resources, but people are particularly prominent in certain business models. For example, human resources are crucial in knowledge-intensive and creative industries. A pharmaceutical company such as Novartis, for example, relies heavily on human resources: its business model is predicated on an army of experienced scientists and a large and skilled sales force.
Financial: Some business models call for financial resources and/or financial guarantees, such as cash, lines of credit, or a stock option pool for hiring key employees. Ericsson, the telecom manufacturer, provides an example of financial resource leverage within a business model. Ericsson may opt to borrow funds from banks and capital markets, then use a portion of the proceeds to provide vendor financing to equipment customers, thus ensuring that orders are placed with Ericsson rather than competitors."""	"""Discussion (5 minutes)
Prompt:
What are key resources? How do we get them?
Potential answers:
Key resources are the personnel, tools, and budget the team will need access to.
Every business model requires Key Resources—these enable an enterprise to:
Create and offer a Value Proposition
Reach markets and maintain Customer Relationships
Generate Revenue Streams
Different businesses rely on different types of key resources.
Some require high cash flow (e.g., retail, manufacturing).
Others rely on skilled human resources (e.g., consulting, software development).
Key resources can be owned, leased, or acquired from key partners (e.g., investors, suppliers, collaborators).

Refining the Discussion with Values & Resilience Considerations
Expand the conversation beyond traditional resources by integrating values-aligned resources:
How do your key resources align with your values?
Example: Tech company deciding between high-speed but energy-intensive servers vs. solar-powered servers.
Which resources are most vulnerable to supply chain disruptions, price volatility, or regulation changes?
Example: Businesses that relied on non-renewable materials saw supply chain delays during COVID.
Mitigation: Consider sustainable alternatives that increase stability and reduce long-term costs.
How could prioritizing sustainability or ethical sourcing make your business more resilient?
Example: Fair-trade coffee brands secure long-term supplier loyalty, ensuring stable pricing.

Key Resource Categories & Considerations
1. Physical Resources:
Facilities, buildings, vehicles, hardware, logistics networks
Values Lens: Are these resources energy-efficient, responsibly sourced, or adaptable?
Example: A logistics company using fuel-efficient vehicles to reduce costs and emissions.
2. Intellectual Property (IP):
Brand identity, patents, proprietary technology, databases, algorithms
Values Lens: Are these resources accessible, open-source, or ethically developed?
Example: Open-source software companies that enable collaboration while maintaining a revenue model.
3. Human Resources:
Employees, contractors, advisors
Values Lens: Are hiring, retention, and training practices equitable, ethical, and inclusive?
Example: Businesses that provide fair wages and growth opportunities retain employees longer.
4. Financial Resources:
Capital, investments, revenue streams
Values Lens: Is funding aligned with the company’s mission? Are there ethical finance models?
Example: A sustainable brand choosing impact investors over venture capital for long-term alignment.

Activity – Resource Resilience Mapping (10 minutes)
Goal: Help participants assess their resources beyond traditional needs—considering values, resilience, and efficiency.
List Your Resources: Identify the key resources required for business success.
Assess Their Alignment: Are these resources chosen for cost, speed, sustainability, ethics, or resilience?
Risk Assessment:
Which resources are most vulnerable to price fluctuations, shortages, or regulatory changes?
Can alternatives improve stability? (e.g., renewable energy, local sourcing)
Values Integration:
How could sustainability, ethics, or durability enhance long-term success?
Example: If using imported raw materials, could switching to local suppliers reduce risk and support community businesses?
Reflection: Discuss findings with a partner or small group—what surprised them? Any action items identified?""
"

	-	9	Added New Content	"There were two previous examples of WHAT IF YOU DON'T PROTOTYPE?: Better Place and Juicero."	"""Replace two previous examples with The QOWA
3 minutes: Lecture

QOWA (meaning ""strength"" in Arabic) was an ambitious 2007 initiative by UNICEF Innovation Unit that aimed to:
Provide quality education to children affected by the Iraqi conflicts
Create a community of learners and teachers across borders
Use simple technology solutions to connect children
Help restore normalcy and resilience for conflict-affected children
Roll out across multiple countries in the Middle East region
Why QOWA Failed in Prototyping?
1. Failure to Design with the User (Principle 1)
Project plans were developed by experts without involving the end users (out-of-school Iraqi children)
Lacked understanding of actual resources, needs, challenges, and usage patterns of the target population
Failed to conduct proper field research on how people access and use information
Did not budget or plan for the logistical complexity of including end users in the design process
2. Lack of Incremental Development
Did not build rapid prototypes that could be tested and modified iteratively
Created large-scale regional project plans that were lengthy and expensive to implement
Once implemented, the cost (time, money, organizational) to adapt was prohibitively high
The approach resembled an ""all-or-nothing"" gamble where the pilot either succeeded or died
3. Overambitious Scope (Principle 7: Reuse and Improve)
The concept was ""ahead of its time"" in multiple dimensions:
Hardware and software capabilities
Logistics in conflict zones
Connectivity infrastructure
Technical capacity
Partnership structures
Tried to build ""a massive, globally interconnected classroom and resource library"" in ""the most resource-scarce and conflict-affected areas""
Lacked organizational experience in implementing innovations of this scale and complexity

Source: https://www.unicef.org/innovation/stories/learning-failures-part-1"""

	5	6	Added New Content	"""5-10 minutes: Discussion + lecture

Ask: From what you understand, what are the different types of costs? Can someone give me a few examples
Write all answers on the whiteboard or Jamboard. Group answers so that you get categories for COGS, salaries, and SG&A (you can have other groups if necessary). 
Potential answers:
Entrepreneurs will give a variety of answers, write them all down.
Group their answers to highlight the costs below:
Cost of Goods Sold (COGS): These are the direct costs of producing an item sold by a company. This includes the cost of the materials and labor directly used to create the product itself.
Salaries: This includes your team and staff that you pay on a monthly basis (if you pay them in direct relation to production of your product, it might be considered in the COGS section).
Selling, general, and administrative (SG&A): These include additional costs that are not related to the production of what you are selling.
Start up costs: This is all the money you need to start your business. We did this during Ignite so you should already have it. You should consider the bigger capital expenditures you need to start, but also any operating expenses that will allow your business to run while you are waiting to become profitable.
Operating Expenses (OP-EX): Direct costs involved in day to day operation. This can include things such as marketing expenses, supplies, salaries, etc. These could be fixed or variable.
Capital Expenditure: One time purchases that relate to the long term business success (items that will last at least 1 year or longer). This can include things like computers, machines, land, furniture, etc…
Fixed Costs: These are costs that stay the same month to month. Rent for example (you agree on your rent and pay the same amount month to month). 
Variable costs: These are costs that change over time. Production for example (the more you produce, the more expenses you pay)

1 minute: Transition
Today, we will talk in more detail about COGS, Salaries, and SG&A.  These are the things that will be highlighted in your profit and loss for the most part.
Next week we will go deeper in your start up costs and apply the capital expenditure vs operating expenditure concepts."""	"""5-10 minutes: Discussion + lecture
Ask: From what you understand, what are the different types of costs? Can someone give me a few examples 
Write all answers on the whiteboard or Jamboard. 
Group answers so that you get categories for COGS, salaries, and SG&A (you can have other groups if necessary). 

Potential Answer
Entrepreneurs will give a variety of answers, write them all down.
Group their answers to highlight the costs below:
Cost of Goods Sold (COGS): Direct costs of producing an item sold by a company (e.g., materials, direct labor).
Salaries: Team and staff payments (if directly tied to production, might be COGS).
Selling, general, and administrative (SG&A): Indirect costs like rent, marketing, and overhead.

Consider your costs strategically, they represent what you care about and communicate that to your customers:
Costs reflect values: Do you prioritize efficiency, quality, or resilience?
Efficiencies save money over time: Smart investments (e.g., longer-lasting materials, reducing waste, energy-efficient choices) can lower costs long-term.
Example: Switching to LED lights may have an upfront cost but reduces long-term electricity expenses.

Activity Prompt (Discussion 5-10 min):
What costs matter most to your business?
How could aligning with values help manage risks and costs?
Example: If your priority is operational efficiency, would bulk ordering, material choices, or equipment upgrades help lower costs over time?
Group responses into COGS, Salaries, SG&A as before.

Next week we will go deeper in your start up costs, including capital expenditure vs. operating expenditure.."""

10. Balance Sheet	7	7	Added New Content	"CAP-EX OR OP-EX?"	"Consider to remove it and replace with the next slide"
	-	7	Added New Content	-	"""Resource Efficiency & CAP-EX, OP-EX
Resource efficiency investments can be either CAPEX or OPEX:
CAPEX: Long-term assets that provide efficiency over time.
Example: Solar panels (25+ years), energy-efficient equipment (5–10 years), water recycling systems (10+ years).
OPEX: Short-term operational expenses that improve efficiency.
Example: LED bulbs (if inexpensive), energy audits, staff training on conservation

Example:
A $3,000 solar panel investment is a CAPEX item that depreciates over 25 years, while an LED retrofit at $200 might be an OPEX cost.

Facilitator notes:
5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

Operating Expenses (OP-EX): Direct costs involved in day to day operation. These could be fixed or variable. These are operational costs that contribute to your business running normally. You probably have to pay for these things every month or on a frequent basis.
Ask: Can someone give me a few examples of operational costs? 
What about resource efficiency expenses that fall under OPEX?
Potential answers:
Marketing and advertisements,
Travel,
Rent,
Meetings,
Supplies, 
Salaries, 
Energy audits
Eco-certifications
Staff training on sustainability practices.
etc. 
Capital Expenditure: Capital expenditure, or CapEx, are funds used by a company to acquire or upgrade physical assets. These are one time purchases that relate to the long term business success (items that will last at least 1 year or longer). These items aren’t purchased frequently because they last a long time.
Ask: Can someone give me a few examples of capital expenditures? 
Can anyone think of an example where an investment in efficiency measures might be categorized as CAPEX?
Potential answers:
Computers
Machines
Land/property
Furniture
IP/legal registration/patents
Even the money you spend renovating your space count as CAP-EX
Other investments that will last over 1 year
Etc…
Solar panels
Energy-efficient HVAC systems
Water-saving fixtures."""

PURPOSE: This slide introduces efficiency investments as a strategic category of capital expenditures that generate ongoing financial benefits.

PRESENTATION (5 minutes):

2. Walk through each example:
   - ""A solar panel installation costs $3,000 upfront, but saves $80/month in electricity. Over its 25-year lifespan, it will generate $24,000 in savings.""
   - ""LED lighting has a faster payback period of just over 2 years, then continues saving money for 3+ more years.""
   - ""Water-saving systems can both reduce utility bills and protect against water shortages.""

3. Emphasize the dual benefits:
   - ""These investments appear on your balance sheet exactly like any other fixed asset.""
   - ""But unlike many other assets, they actively reduce your monthly expenses.""
   - ""This means they directly improve your profitability after the payback period.""

DISCUSSION PROMPT (3 minutes):
- ""What utility expenses in your business consistently increase year after year?""
- ""Are there any efficiency investments that would make sense for your specific business model?""

TRANSITION TO NEXT SLIDE:
""Now let's continue with categorizing your startup costs as either expenses or assets that you'll capitalize."""""

Instead, focus on setting the stage and bringing your interviewees on board so they’re comfortable enough to be, and remain, open with you. What you do at this stage can include the following:
Telling participants what topics will be covered
Telling participants how their data will be used
Asking innocuous questions such as what their role is in their organization
Asking concrete questions that are easy to answer

Middle: In the middle of the interview, you’re hitting high gear. Having established a direct channel with your interviewees (the users), you move on and ask the bulk of your questions, but maybe not in the order you had originally planned. Remember to:
Keep the flow of the conversation as natural as possible, but cover the topics you want to cover.
Pick up on what participants have said earlier and get full replies to questions they have only partially answered.
Steer participants back on track if they go too far off topic.
Show that you have been listening.
Go deeper where necessary

End: At the end of the interview, you wrap up in a way that makes participants feel as though they have said what they wanted to say and that their answers are valuable. By this point, you will have managed to tie up any loose ends on matters that had not been clear before, and both you and they should be satisfied that the interview has brought all the issues out into the open. Things you should do include:
Asking if there is anything participants would like to add.
Telling your participants what you are going to do with their data and what the value is for them.
Thanking them for taking the time to help with your research. Above all, remember to conduct a pilot study before you start approaching real-life participants and tackling ‘organic’ interview settings. Also, always be sensitive to the fact that people are different and need different things!"	"Effective Questions:
- ""Tell me about your decision-making process...""
- ""What matters most when choosing [product/service]?""
- ""What challenges do you face with current solutions?""
- ""How do you evaluate different options?""

Avoid:
- Leading questions about specific features
- Yes/no questions about purchasing
- Questions that assume user needs
Facilitator Notes:

Focus on open-ended questions that reveal genuine insights
Let participants develop questions relevant to their business
If efficiency or cost topics arise, explore naturally
Time: 10 minutes practice
Encourage questions that uncover real user needs and behaviors"

The Five One Labs curriculum has been comprehensively enhanced with climate resilience concepts, improving from an average score of 5.9 (Significant Integration Gaps) to 18.9 (Strong Integration).

Integration Strategy

Our integration approach followed a strategic pathway to ensure comprehensive, coherent curriculum enhancement:

  1. Foundation Setting (Ignite Modules): Enhanced user research and market analysis to incorporate sustainability considerations from the earliest stages of business ideation.
  2. Core Business Model Integration (Early Incubator Modules): Embedded sustainability into fundamental business structures through the BMC, cost model, and financial planning modules.
  3. Operational Integration (Mid Incubator Modules): Applied sustainability principles to key operational areas including service design, marketing, and organizational structure.
  4. Advanced Integration (Late Incubator Modules): Incorporated sustainability into sophisticated business aspects including ethics, financing, risk management, and investment readiness.

Module 3: Business Model Canvas (BMC)

Initial Assessment: The original BMC module focused on standard business model components without sustainability considerations.

Key Changes: Integrated sustainability into all BMC components; added green revenue streams and partnerships; incorporated resource efficiency into cost structures

Dimension Before After Improvement Notes
Business Value Focus 2 5 +3 Reframed sustainability as revenue driver and cost reducer
Practical Application 1 4 +3 Added concrete tools for identifying green revenue streams
Local Relevance 2 4 +2 Incorporated Iraqi examples like KESK solar business model
Core Integration 2 5 +3 Embedded sustainability throughout all nine BMC components
Resource Efficiency 1 4 +3 Added focus on resource optimization in key resources
TOTAL 8 22 +14 Transformation from basic to comprehensive sustainable business design

Assessment Methodology

Scoring Dimensions

Each module was evaluated on five key dimensions of climate integration:

  1. Business Value Focus (BV): How well the module connects sustainability to tangible business benefits (0-5)
  2. Practical Application (PA): The inclusion of actionable tools and exercises for implementation (0-5)
  3. Local Relevance (LR): How well the content relates to Iraqi context and challenges (0-5)
  4. Core Integration (CI): Whether sustainability is integrated into core concepts vs. added as a separate topic (0-5)
  5. Resource Efficiency (RE): Focus on operational efficiency and resource optimization (0-5)

Scoring Scale

For each dimension:

  • 0: No integration
  • 1: Minimal/token mention
  • 2: Basic integration but superficial
  • 3: Moderate integration with some depth
  • 4: Strong integration throughout most content
  • 5: Comprehensive integration as a central theme

Total Score Interpretation

0-5: Critical Need for Integration
6-10: Significant Integration Gaps
11-15: Basic Integration Present
16-20: Strong Integration
21-25: Exemplary Climate Integration

Prioritization Factors

Modules were prioritized based on:

  1. Initial score (lower scores indicating greater need)
  2. Strategic importance for entrepreneur development
  3. Potential for business impact through climate integration
  4. Logical sequence in the learning journey

I'll review the Climate Integration Dashboard website based on the actual changes you made to the Five One Labs curriculum as shown in your documents. The current dashboard is a template with placeholder data and visuals, so I'll provide recommendations to update it based on the real changes you implemented.

## Dashboard Review & Recommendations

### Main Dashboard Updates

1. **Module Count Accuracy**
   - The dashboard shows 22 modules enhanced, but your documents indicate more comprehensive updates across both Ignite and Incubator programs
   - The scoring system (using 0-25 scale) appears arbitrary compared to the actual integration approach you took

2. **Integration Strategy Representation**
   - Your approach was more nuanced than shown - focusing on business efficiency, resource optimization, risk management, and value alignment
   - The dashboard should reflect your "business-first" approach rather than explicit climate framing

3. **Key Tools Implementation**
   - The dashboard doesn't highlight the actual tools you created (Business Efficiency Workbook, Risk Assessment Process, etc.)
   - Your integration focused on practical business tools rather than abstract climate concepts

### Specific Content Updates

#### Module Improvements Section
Rather than abstract scores, the dashboard should show:
- Actual slide additions (e.g., 54+ new slides added)
- New worksheets created (Business Efficiency Workbook, Risk Category tool)
- Content types (updated speaker notes, new discussion prompts, new examples)

#### Integration Approach Representation
The current "Foundation Setting → Advanced Integration" progression doesn't accurately reflect your approach. It should include:
- **Business-First Framing**: How you positioned sustainability as operational efficiency
- **Risk & Resilience**: Your integration of risk assessment and business continuity
- **Value-Based Business**: How you incorporated values alignment with profitability

#### Local Examples
The dashboard mentions Iraqi examples but should highlight the specific ones you used:
- UNDP Accelerator Lab prototyping example
- Al-Eiz Takeaway Kitchen case study
- Iraq Central Bank green financing section

### Suggested Dashboard Improvements

1. **Replace abstract scoring system** with concrete metrics:
   - Number of modules enhanced (with accurate count)
   - Number of new slides added
   - Number of practical tools created
   - Types of integration methods used

2. **Create an "Implementation Approach" section** showing:
   - Business efficiency as primary frame (not explicit climate messaging)
   - Risk assessment integration into business planning
   - Values-driven leadership that aligns with profitability

3. **Highlight key practical tools** you created:
   - Business Efficiency Workbook 
   - Risk Assessment Process tool
   - Various new worksheets (e.g., Business Viability Matrix)

4. **Showcase concrete examples** of integration techniques:
   - How you incorporated efficiency into cost models
   - How you added resource optimization to supply chain module
   - How you integrated resilience into BMC discussions

Would you like me to provide a more detailed mockup of what the updated dashboard could look like, or would you prefer specific content recommendations for particular sections?

# Page 1: Homepage

input.title: Five One Labs - Climate Integration Dashboard Homepage
input.content:
Five One Labs - Business Resilience Integration

Curriculum Enhancement Project | March 2025

Project Overview

In 2025, Five One Labs enhanced its flagship entrepreneurship curriculum—the Ignite Pre-Incubator and Incubator programs—to equip Iraqi entrepreneurs with the tools, knowledge, and skills to build more resilient, efficient, and future-proof businesses.

Rather than creating standalone "climate modules," we integrated business efficiency, risk management, and value-aligned leadership principles throughout the existing curriculum. This approach ensures entrepreneurs view these topics as core business concepts rather than optional add-ons.

Modules Enhanced

32

Across both programs

New Slides Added

54+

New material integrated

New Tools Created

5

Practical assessment frameworks

Case Studies Added

8

Featuring Iraqi businesses

Integration Approach

Our approach focused on four key principles to ensure the changes would create tangible business value rather than just theoretical climate knowledge:

1

Business-First Framework

We framed sustainability concepts in business terms—focusing on cost savings, operational efficiency, and competitive advantages. Rather than emphasizing environmental impact, we highlighted how resource optimization directly improves business performance and profitability.

2

Risk & Resilience Integration

We incorporated risk assessment tools that help entrepreneurs identify resource vulnerabilities, supply chain disruptions, and market shifts. These tools enable businesses to develop mitigation strategies that improve long-term viability.

Example: The Risk Category Worksheet helps entrepreneurs quantify business risks related to resource costs, supply security, and market changes, then prioritize actions based on potential business impact.
3

Practical Tools & Frameworks

We created concrete, actionable tools that entrepreneurs can immediately apply to their businesses, focusing on measurable improvements rather than abstract concepts.

Example: The Business Efficiency Workbook provides structured assessments for identifying cost-saving opportunities in energy use, materials, water, transportation, and supply chain management.
4

Values-Driven Leadership

We expanded the curriculum to show how aligning business operations with core values can create stronger market differentiation, customer loyalty, and employee engagement—creating additional pathways to business success beyond traditional models.

Example: In the Business Ethics module, we added frameworks for measuring impact across the triple bottom line (People, Planet, Profit) while maintaining a focus on viable business models.

Explore the Curriculum Enhancements

Ignite Pre-Incubator Enhancements Incubator Program Enhancements New Tools & Frameworks
📊

Business Efficiency Focus

Rather than adding climate-specific content, we integrated practical efficiency concepts throughout the curriculum. For example, in the Cost Model module, we added ROI calculations for resource efficiency investments like solar panels and LED lighting.

This approach ensures entrepreneurs see resource optimization as a core business strategy rather than an environmental add-on.

🔄

Iraqi Context & Examples

We incorporated locally relevant examples like:

  • Al-Eiz Takeaway Kitchen in Qaim as a resource-efficient business model
  • UNDP Accelerator Lab's prototyping approach in Iraq
  • Iraq Central Bank's green financing initiatives

These examples demonstrate how efficiency principles apply in the local business environment.

🛠️

New Worksheets & Tools

We developed practical tools that entrepreneurs can immediately apply:

  • Business Efficiency Workbook
  • Risk Assessment Process Worksheet
  • Business Viability Matrix
  • Extreme User Interview Framework
  • Green Funding Opportunities Guide

These tools translate concepts into actionable business improvements.

© 2025 Five One Labs - Climate Connect: Entrepreneurial Resilience & Action

Funded by: IOM's WASL Civil Society Fund under the Climate Action for Resilience and Sustainability (CARS) initiative

input.content:
Five One Labs - Ignite Pre-Incubator Enhancements

Integration of Business Resilience Concepts

Ignite Program Overview

The Ignite Pre-Incubator program is Five One Labs' foundational entrepreneurship curriculum, guiding aspiring entrepreneurs from initial idea to viable concept. We enhanced 7 key modules to integrate business efficiency, risk management, and values alignment from the earliest stages of entrepreneurial thinking.

Our integration strategy focused on three key areas:

  1. User Understanding: Expanded research frameworks to capture resource needs, efficiency preferences, and values alignment in user personas and journeys
  2. Market Analysis: Added efficiency and resilience as competitive factors in market research and opportunity assessment
  3. Idea Generation: Infused brainstorming and evaluation processes with considerations for resource optimization and long-term viability
High Priority Modules
All Modules

Module 2: User Research

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Added new slide on researching business challenges that includes customer decision drivers and external factors
  • Expanded user research process to identify resource constraints and efficiency preferences
  • Created new "Extreme User Interview Worksheet" to capture insights from users with resource constraints
  • Enhanced observation prompts to include sustainability-related behaviors
  • Added new slide on market shifts and adaptability

Example: Enhanced Interview Prompts

Before

"Tell me about the last time you…"

After

"Tell me about the last time you made a decision based on price, convenience, or long-term value."

Added: "What drives their choices—cost, reliability, or ease of access? Are there patterns in what they prioritize?"

New Worksheet: Extreme User Interview Framework

Created a structured interview guide for researchers to understand users at different ends of the spectrum, including:

  • Power users who use products most frequently
  • Users in challenging environments or with limited resources
  • Cost-sensitive users with budget constraints
  • Users with unique needs or accessibility requirements

Module 4: Market Research

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Added new content on cost trends affecting businesses (energy prices, supply chain shifts, regulations)
  • Expanded competitive benchmarking framework to include energy efficiency, material use, and sustainable supply chain factors
  • Added discussion on external trends that could increase operating costs
  • Created new slide on financial planning and smart growth
  • Added slide on business benefits of sustainability focused on cost savings

Example: Enhanced Competitive Benchmarking

Before

Standard benchmarking factors:

  • Products
  • Price
  • Service
  • Location
  • Sales Method
After

Enhanced benchmarking factors adding:

  • Energy Efficiency
  • Material use & waste
  • Sustainable supply chain
  • Green marketing & branding

Module 6: Creativity and Ideation

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Added efficiency considerations to brainstorming guidelines
  • Added new slide with guiding questions about efficiency, materials, and cost savings
  • Enhanced "What if?" scenarios to include resource constraints and market shifts
  • Added efficiency and adaptability to idea evaluation criteria
  • Created new Business Viability Matrix Worksheet
  • Introduced Business Efficiency Workbook and Risk Assessment Process tools

Example: Enhanced Brainstorming Rules

Before
  • Start with "How Might We"
  • No judgment or criticism
  • Go for weird, wacky and wild ideas
  • Quantity over quality
  • Be visual
  • One conversation at a time
After
  • Start with "How Might We"
  • No judgment or criticism
  • Go for weird, wacky and wild ideas
  • Consider efficiency and costs
  • Consider green efficiency opportunities
  • Quantity over quality
  • Be visual
  • One conversation at a time

Module 7: The Pitch

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Updated slide content to focus on efficiency and value in pitch communications
  • Added discussion questions about highlighting efficiency and risk reduction in pitches
  • Updated pitch examples to incorporate efficiency and resilience
  • Added impact-driven pitch and green innovation factor to judging criteria

Example: Enhanced Pitch Example

Before

"Tourism App is a mobile application to help tourists easily experience the real Kurdish culture."

After

"Eco-Tourism App connects visitors with authentic Kurdish experiences while promoting sustainable travel practices that benefit local communities."

Note added: "Notice how this example incorporates sustainability while highlighting benefits for both customers and local communities."

Module 1: Design Thinking

Medium Priority

Key Changes:

  • Updated wording in slides to include "future-proof" in the program description
  • Added "Identify risks and efficiencies" to the business skills list
  • Enhanced 3-year business strategy description to include risk and efficiency management

Module 3: The Survey

Lower Priority

Key Changes:

  • This module received minimal enhancements as it was a lower priority for integration

Five One Labs - Incubator Program Enhancements

Integration of Business Resilience Concepts

Incubator Program Overview

The Incubator Program provides more in-depth training for entrepreneurs with validated business ideas. We enhanced 25 modules to integrate business efficiency, risk management, and values alignment throughout the entire business development journey.

Our integration strategy was structured across four thematic areas:

  1. Business Model Integration: Enhanced core business planning modules (BMC, Cost Model, Balance Sheet) to incorporate resource efficiency and resilience
  2. Operations Optimization: Added efficiency considerations to service design, supply chain, and production processes
  3. Values-Based Leadership: Expanded ethics, personal brand, and leadership modules to connect values with business success
  4. Risk Management: Added tools and frameworks for identifying, assessing, and mitigating resource and market risks
Featured Modules
All Modules
By Theme

Module 3: Business Model Canvas

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Added sustainable BMC as an option with two new segments: People and Planet
  • Added discussion of values alignment and sustainability as market differentiation factors
  • Enhanced BMC components with shared value illustrations
  • Added resilience assumptions to customer hypotheses
  • Enhanced Key Resources discussion with values & resilience considerations

Example: Enhanced Key Resources Discussion

Before

Basic discussion of physical, intellectual, human, and financial resources focused primarily on acquisition.

After

Expanded to include:

  • Resource Resilience: "Which resources are most vulnerable to price fluctuations, shortages, or regulatory changes?"
  • Values Integration: "How could sustainability, ethics, or durability enhance long-term success?"
  • Resource efficiency examples: "If using imported raw materials, could switching to local suppliers reduce risk and support community businesses?"

Module 9: Cost Model

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Added new slide discussing strategic efficiency investments with cost-benefit analysis
  • Reframed costs to reflect values and priorities
  • Added activity prompts about cost reduction through efficiency
  • Added resource efficiency discussions to cost analysis
  • Enhanced overhead cost discussions to include efficiency savings

Example: Strategic Efficiency Investments

Added concrete ROI calculations for efficiency investments:

Investment Initial Cost Annual Savings Payback Period
Solar Panels $3,000 $960 3.1 years
LED Lighting $500 $240 2.1 years
Water Systems $800 $300 2.7 years

Module 25: Supply Chain

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Added resource efficiency as a key learning objective
  • Enhanced production discussion to include material choices and efficiency
  • Integrated Business Efficiency Checklist into supply chain analysis
  • Added activity to identify resource optimization opportunities
  • Created transfer process from supply chain mapping to Business Efficiency Workbook

Example: Enhanced Production Discussion

Before

"All of you have great ideas, but if you can't make and deliver your product/service to the market, then your business will fail! Some planes were priced really high because they were really amazing, but it was too much for them to deliver!"

After

"All of you have great ideas, but if you can't make and deliver your product/service to the market efficiently, then your business will fail! When developing your product, think about:

  • How it will be produced efficiently
  • How it will be shipped at the lowest cost
  • How it will be stored without waste
  • How it will be packaged to balance protection and material use

The best businesses optimize both customer experience AND operational efficiency."

Module 27: Business Ethics

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Reframed learning objectives to integrate triple bottom line (People, Planet, Profit)
  • Added discussions on authenticity as a business advantage
  • Enhanced values discussion to include living values vs. marketing them
  • Added sections on business resilience through value alignment
  • Provided frameworks for measuring impact while maintaining business focus

Example: Values as Business Advantage

Added data-driven content showing business benefits:

  • Harvard Business School study: "High sustainability" companies outperformed "low sustainability" ones by 4.8% annually over an 18-year period
  • Nielsen survey: 66% of consumers are willing to pay more for products from brands committed to positive social and environmental impact
  • B Lab data: 82% of B Corp-certified organizations remain more resilient during economic downturns

Module 30: Risk and Crisis Management

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Updated learning objectives to include climate impacts and market shifts
  • Added Risk Category Worksheet for structured risk assessment
  • Created connection between Risk Assessment and Business Efficiency Workbook
  • Added supply chain stability and operational costs to risk factors
  • Enhanced decision-making discussion with long-term resilience focus

Example: Risk Evaluation Process

Created a step-by-step evaluation framework:

  1. Risk Categorization: Resource Costs, Supply Security, Operating Stability, Market Changes, Competitive Position
  2. Risk Scoring: Severity (1-3), Likelihood (1-3), Timeframe (1-3)
  3. Prioritization: Calculated score (Severity × Likelihood × Timeframe)
  4. Action Planning: Transfer high-priority risks to Business Efficiency Workbook for implementation

input.title: Five One Labs - New Tools & Frameworks
input.content:
Five One Labs - New Tools & Frameworks

Practical Applications for Entrepreneurs

Tool Development Approach

A core component of our integration strategy was the development of practical tools that entrepreneurs can immediately apply to their businesses. Rather than abstract climate concepts, we created structured frameworks that provide tangible business benefits while strengthening resilience and efficiency.

Our tools were designed with three key principles in mind:

  1. Practical Application: Each tool produces actionable insights that can be immediately implemented
  2. Business Value: All tools directly connect to business performance metrics like cost reduction, risk mitigation, and competitive advantage
  3. Progressive Implementation: Tools support a step-by-step approach that allows gradual implementation of efficiency improvements
📊

Business Efficiency Workbook

The Business Efficiency Workbook is a comprehensive assessment and planning tool that helps entrepreneurs identify, prioritize, and implement efficiency improvements across their operations. It guides users through a systematic process of identifying areas where resource optimization can reduce costs and improve business performance.

Workbook Structure

Tab Purpose Key Components
Business Efficiency Health Check Dashboard overview of efficiency status Status indicators, priority tasks, upcoming actions
Checklist Comprehensive assessment of efficiency practices Assessment sections for power, materials, water, supply chain, etc.
Prioritize Decision framework for selecting improvements Impact analysis, ROI calculation, business relevance scoring
Plan Implementation strategy for selected improvements Assignment of responsibilities, costs, funding sources
Action Tracking system for implementation progress Due dates, status indicators, progress notes
Assessment Categories
  • Power & Equipment
  • Materials & Waste
  • Water & Utilities
  • Supplies & Inputs
  • Transport & Logistics
  • Supply Chain
  • Team & Skills
Business Benefits
  • Lower operating costs
  • Reduced resource vulnerability
  • Improved operational efficiency
  • Structured improvement process
  • Measurable ROI tracking
Implementation Features
  • Prioritization matrix
  • ROI calculation tools
  • Action planning template
  • Progress tracking system
  • Visual health indicators

Sample Application: Energy Efficiency

The workbook helps identify energy efficiency opportunities and calculate returns on investment:

Efficiency Measure Initial Investment Annual Savings Payback Period Business Benefit
Solar panel installation $3,000 $960 3.1 years Reduced electricity costs + backup power during outages
LED lighting retrofit $500 $240 2.1 years Lower energy bills + improved workspace lighting
⚠️

Risk Assessment Process Worksheet

The Risk Assessment Process Worksheet helps entrepreneurs identify, evaluate, and prioritize business risks related to resource constraints, supply chain disruptions, and market shifts. It provides a structured framework for assessing vulnerability and developing mitigation strategies.

Assessment Categories

  • Resource Costs: Risks related to energy, water, and material price fluctuations
  • Supply Security: Risks related to supplier stability and material availability
  • Operating Stability: Risks related to power outages, water shortages, and other operational disruptions
  • Market Changes: Risks related to shifting customer preferences and demand patterns
  • Competitive Position: Risks related to competitors' efficiency and sustainability initiatives
Risk Evaluation Process
  1. Identify potential risks in each category
  2. Rate severity (1-5) of impact if realized
  3. Assess likelihood (1-5) of occurrence
  4. Calculate priority score (severity × likelihood)
  5. Identify business opportunities from each risk
  6. Develop specific action plans for high-priority risks
Integration with Efficiency Tools

The Risk Assessment worksheet connects directly to the Business Efficiency Workbook, allowing entrepreneurs to:

  • Transfer high-priority risks to the efficiency checklist
  • Develop mitigation actions in the planning section
  • Track implementation of risk reduction measures
  • Measure ROI of risk mitigation investments
Business Benefits
  • Proactive risk identification
  • Structured prioritization process
  • Concrete action planning
  • Turning risks into business opportunities
  • Enhanced business resilience

Sample Risk Analysis: Electricity Supply

Risk Category Current Risk Impact Areas Severity (1-5) Likelihood (1-5) Priority Score Business Opportunity Actions Needed
Resource Costs High electricity costs, material waste Power & Equipment 4 5 20 Cost savings through efficiency 1. Install solar panels
2. Improve process efficiency
Operating Stability Power outages Production 5 4 20 Process innovation 1. Install backup systems
2. Train team on efficiency
💰

Green Funding Opportunities Guide

This resource helps entrepreneurs identify and access specialized funding opportunities for efficiency improvements and sustainable business practices. It provides a structured overview of available green financing options in Iraq and the MENA region.

Funding Categories

Category Description Examples
Green Funds & Grants Non-repayable funding for green initiatives Green Climate Fund (GCF), Global Environment Facility (GEF), UNDP Iraq Programs
Climate Finance Initiatives Specialized financing for climate solutions International Solar Alliance (ISA), RCREEE renewable energy programs
Green Business Incentives Preferential loans and subsidies Iraq Central Bank Green Loans ($2K–$50K near-zero interest)
Key Information Provided
  • Funding source name and website
  • Eligibility requirements
  • Application process details
  • Funding amounts available
  • Project types supported
  • Repayment terms (if applicable)
Business Benefits
  • Access to favorable financing terms
  • Reduced capital costs for improvements
  • Technical support often included
  • Enhanced investor attractiveness
  • Accelerated implementation timeline
Integration Features
  • Links to Business Efficiency Workbook
  • Matching tool for improvements and funding
  • ROI calculation incorporating funding
  • Implementation timeline planning

Featured Opportunity: Iraq Central Bank Green Loans

The Iraq Central Bank has committed to sustainable finance through its ESG framework, providing near-zero interest loans for solar installations and efficiency projects ranging from $2,000 to $50,000.

Key benefits include simplified application processes for small businesses, extended repayment periods, and technical support through partner organizations.

input.title: Five One Labs - New Tools & Frameworks
input.new_str:
This tool helps entrepreneurs gather insights from users with unique resource constraints or efficiency preferences. By expanding user research to include "extreme users," entrepreneurs can uncover valuable innovation opportunities that address both business and environmental challenges.

User Categories

  • Power Users: Those who use products/services most frequently and intensively
  • Resource-Constrained Users: Those operating with limited access to energy, water, or materials
  • Cost-Sensitive Users: Those making decisions primarily based on long-term cost efficiency
  • Values-Driven Users: Those prioritizing sustainability and environmental impact in purchases
  • Challenging Environment Users: Those operating in areas with infrastructure limitations
Interview Structure
  1. Resource use patterns and constraints
  2. Cost and efficiency priorities
  3. Adaptations to resource challenges
  4. Long-term value vs. upfront cost considerations
  5. DIY solutions and workarounds
  6. Values and sustainability preferences
Business Applications
  • Identify efficiency-driven innovations
  • Discover resource-efficient alternatives
  • Understand cost-value trade-offs
  • Validate sustainability features
  • Develop adaptable product versions
Integration Features
  • Connects to user persona development
  • Feeds into customer journey mapping
  • Informs product feature prioritization
  • Supports value proposition refinement

Sample Questions:

  • "Tell me about the last time you made a decision based on price, convenience, or long-term value."
  • "What happens when you face resource shortages (electricity, water, etc.) in your daily life?"
  • "What factors drive your choices between upfront costs vs. long-term savings?"
  • "How do you adapt when critical resources are unavailable or too expensive?"
  • "What creative solutions have you developed to deal with resource constraints?"
📋

Business Viability Matrix

The Business Viability Matrix helps entrepreneurs evaluate business ideas through a comprehensive lens that includes efficiency, resilience, and values alignment alongside traditional viability factors. It provides a structured framework for comparing and selecting ideas based on both short-term feasibility and long-term sustainability.

Evaluation Criteria

Category Traditional Factors Enhanced Factors
Market Viability Market size, competition, demand + Growing demand for efficiency, values alignment opportunities
Financial Viability Revenue potential, profit margins, costs + Resource cost stability, efficiency ROI, long-term savings
Technical Viability Technical feasibility, capabilities + Resource optimization potential, adaptability to constraints
Operational Viability Supply chain, production, scalability + Resource efficiency, supply stability, waste reduction
Strategic Viability Competitive advantage, positioning + Values alignment, resilience to market shifts, adaptation capacity
Evaluation Process
  1. Score each idea across all criteria (1-5 scale)
  2. Weight criteria based on business priorities
  3. Calculate weighted scores and rank ideas
  4. Identify opportunities for improvement
  5. Develop implementation roadmap
Business Benefits
  • Comprehensive evaluation framework
  • Balanced short-term and long-term focus
  • Identification of resilience factors
  • Resource efficiency optimization
  • Strategic competitive positioning
Integration Features
  • Connects to ideation process
  • Informs business model development
  • Supports risk assessment
  • Guides market positioning

Integration Strategy & Implementation

These tools were designed to work together as an integrated system to help entrepreneurs build more resilient, efficient businesses. The implementation approach includes:

  • Sequential Introduction: Tools are introduced progressively throughout the curriculum, allowing entrepreneurs to build on previous knowledge
  • Cross-Referencing: Each tool references and connects to others, creating a cohesive system rather than isolated frameworks
  • Practical Application: All tools include hands-on exercises and real-world examples to ensure immediate relevance
  • Iraqi Context: Tools were adapted to reflect local business conditions, resource challenges, and market opportunities

By providing these structured frameworks, Five One Labs has equipped entrepreneurs with practical means to improve business performance while enhancing resilience and efficiency—creating a positive impact for both businesses and the broader environment.

Five One Labs - Incubator Program Enhancements

Integration of Business Resilience Concepts

Incubator Program Overview

The Incubator Program provides more in-depth training for entrepreneurs with validated business ideas. We enhanced 25 modules to integrate business efficiency, risk management, and values alignment throughout the entire business development journey.

Our integration strategy was structured across four thematic areas:

  1. Business Model Integration: Enhanced core business planning modules (BMC, Cost Model, Balance Sheet) to incorporate resource efficiency and resilience
  2. Operations Optimization: Added efficiency considerations to service design, supply chain, and production processes
  3. Values-Based Leadership: Expanded ethics, personal brand, and leadership modules to connect values with business success
  4. Risk Management: Added tools and frameworks for identifying, assessing, and mitigating resource and market risks
Featured Modules
All Modules
By Theme

Module 3: Business Model Canvas

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Added sustainable BMC as an option with two new segments: People and Planet
  • Added discussion of values alignment and sustainability as market differentiation factors
  • Enhanced BMC components with shared value illustrations
  • Added resilience assumptions to customer hypotheses
  • Enhanced Key Resources discussion with values & resilience considerations

Example: Enhanced Key Resources Discussion

Before

Basic discussion of physical, intellectual, human, and financial resources focused primarily on acquisition.

After

Expanded to include:

  • Resource Resilience: "Which resources are most vulnerable to price fluctuations, shortages, or regulatory changes?"
  • Values Integration: "How could sustainability, ethics, or durability enhance long-term success?"
  • Resource efficiency examples: "If using imported raw materials, could switching to local suppliers reduce risk and support community businesses?"

Module 9: Cost Model

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Added new slide discussing strategic efficiency investments with cost-benefit analysis
  • Reframed costs to reflect values and priorities
  • Added activity prompts about cost reduction through efficiency
  • Added resource efficiency discussions to cost analysis
  • Enhanced overhead cost discussions to include efficiency savings

Example: Strategic Efficiency Investments

Added concrete ROI calculations for efficiency investments:

Investment Initial Cost Annual Savings Payback Period
Solar Panels $3,000 $960 3.1 years
LED Lighting $500 $240 2.1 years
Water Systems $800 $300 2.7 years

Module 25: Supply Chain

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Added resource efficiency as a key learning objective
  • Enhanced production discussion to include material choices and efficiency
  • Integrated Business Efficiency Checklist into supply chain analysis
  • Added activity to identify resource optimization opportunities
  • Created transfer process from supply chain mapping to Business Efficiency Workbook

Example: Enhanced Production Discussion

Before

"All of you have great ideas, but if you can't make and deliver your product/service to the market, then your business will fail! Some planes were priced really high because they were really amazing, but it was too much for them to deliver!"

After

"All of you have great ideas, but if you can't make and deliver your product/service to the market efficiently, then your business will fail! When developing your product, think about:

  • How it will be produced efficiently
  • How it will be shipped at the lowest cost
  • How it will be stored without waste
  • How it will be packaged to balance protection and material use

The best businesses optimize both customer experience AND operational efficiency."

Module 27: Business Ethics

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Reframed learning objectives to integrate triple bottom line (People, Planet, Profit)
  • Added discussions on authenticity as a business advantage
  • Enhanced values discussion to include living values vs. marketing them
  • Added sections on business resilience through value alignment
  • Provided frameworks for measuring impact while maintaining business focus

Example: Values as Business Advantage

Added data-driven content showing business benefits:

  • Harvard Business School study: "High sustainability" companies outperformed "low sustainability" ones by 4.8% annually over an 18-year period
  • Nielsen survey: 66% of consumers are willing to pay more for products from brands committed to positive social and environmental impact
  • B Lab data: 82% of B Corp-certified organizations remain more resilient during economic downturns

Module 30: Risk and Crisis Management

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Updated learning objectives to include climate impacts and market shifts
  • Added Risk Category Worksheet for structured risk assessment
  • Created connection between Risk Assessment and Business Efficiency Workbook
  • Added supply chain stability and operational costs to risk factors
  • Enhanced decision-making discussion with long-term resilience focus

Example: Risk Evaluation Process

Created a step-by-step evaluation framework:

  1. Risk Categorization: Resource Costs, Supply Security, Operating Stability, Market Changes, Competitive Position
  2. Risk Scoring: Severity (1-3), Likelihood (1-3), Timeframe (1-3)
  3. Prioritization: Calculated score (Severity + Likelihood + Timeframe)
  4. Action Planning: Transfer high-priority risks to Business Efficiency Workbook for implementation

Five One Labs - Incubator Program Enhancements

Integration of Business Resilience Concepts

Incubator Program Overview

The Incubator Program provides more in-depth training for entrepreneurs with validated business ideas. We enhanced 25 modules to integrate business efficiency, risk management, and values alignment throughout the entire business development journey.

Our integration strategy was structured across four thematic areas:

  1. Business Model Integration: Enhanced core business planning modules (BMC, Cost Model, Balance Sheet) to incorporate resource efficiency and resilience
  2. Operations Optimization: Added efficiency considerations to service design, supply chain, and production processes
  3. Values-Based Leadership: Expanded ethics, personal brand, and leadership modules to connect values with business success
  4. Risk Management: Added tools and frameworks for identifying, assessing, and mitigating resource and market risks
Featured Modules
All Modules
By Theme

Module 3: Business Model Canvas

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Added sustainable BMC as an option with two new segments: People and Planet
  • Added discussion of values alignment and sustainability as market differentiation factors
  • Enhanced BMC components with shared value illustrations
  • Added resilience assumptions to customer hypotheses
  • Enhanced Key Resources discussion with values & resilience considerations

Example: Enhanced Key Resources Discussion

Before

Basic discussion of physical, intellectual, human, and financial resources focused primarily on acquisition.

After

Expanded to include:

  • Resource Resilience: "Which resources are most vulnerable to price fluctuations, shortages, or regulatory changes?"
  • Values Integration: "How could sustainability, ethics, or durability enhance long-term success?"
  • Resource efficiency examples: "If using imported raw materials, could switching to local suppliers reduce risk and support community businesses?"

Module 9: Cost Model

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Added new slide discussing strategic efficiency investments with cost-benefit analysis
  • Reframed costs to reflect values and priorities
  • Added activity prompts about cost reduction through efficiency
  • Added resource efficiency discussions to cost analysis
  • Enhanced overhead cost discussions to include efficiency savings

Example: Strategic Efficiency Investments

Added concrete ROI calculations for efficiency investments:

Investment Initial Cost Annual Savings Payback Period
Solar Panels $3,000 $960 3.1 years
LED Lighting $500 $240 2.1 years
Water Systems $800 $300 2.7 years

Module 25: Supply Chain

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Added resource efficiency as a key learning objective
  • Enhanced production discussion to include material choices and efficiency
  • Integrated Business Efficiency Checklist into supply chain analysis
  • Added activity to identify resource optimization opportunities
  • Created transfer process from supply chain mapping to Business Efficiency Workbook

Example: Enhanced Production Discussion

Before

"All of you have great ideas, but if you can't make and deliver your product/service to the market, then your business will fail! Some planes were priced really high because they were really amazing, but it was too much for them to deliver!"

After

"All of you have great ideas, but if you can't make and deliver your product/service to the market efficiently, then your business will fail! When developing your product, think about:

  • How it will be produced efficiently
  • How it will be shipped at the lowest cost
  • How it will be stored without waste
  • How it will be packaged to balance protection and material use

The best businesses optimize both customer experience AND operational efficiency."

Module 27: Business Ethics

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Reframed learning objectives to integrate triple bottom line (People, Planet, Profit)
  • Added discussions on authenticity as a business advantage
  • Enhanced values discussion to include living values vs. marketing them
  • Added sections on business resilience through value alignment
  • Provided frameworks for measuring impact while maintaining business focus

Example: Values as Business Advantage

Added data-driven content showing business benefits:

  • Harvard Business School study: "High sustainability" companies outperformed "low sustainability" ones by 4.8% annually over an 18-year period
  • Nielsen survey: 66% of consumers are willing to pay more for products from brands committed to positive social and environmental impact
  • B Lab data: 82% of B Corp-certified organizations remain more resilient during economic downturns

Module 30: Risk and Crisis Management

High Priority

Key Changes:

  • Updated learning objectives to include climate impacts and market shifts
  • Added Risk Category Worksheet for structured risk assessment
  • Created connection between Risk Assessment and Business Efficiency Workbook
  • Added supply chain stability and operational costs to risk factors
  • Enhanced decision-making discussion with long-term resilience focus

Example: Risk Evaluation Process

Created a step-by-step evaluation framework:

  1. Risk Categorization: Resource Costs, Supply Security, Operating Stability, Market Changes, Competitive Position
  2. Risk Scoring: Severity (1-3), Likelihood (1-3), Timeframe (1-3)
  3. Prioritization: Calculated score (Severity × Likelihood × Timeframe)
  4. Action Planning: Transfer high-priority risks to Business Efficiency Workbook for implementation

Five One Labs - Business Resilience Integration

Curriculum Enhancement Project | February 2025

Project Overview

In 2025, Five One Labs enhanced its flagship entrepreneurship curriculum—the Ignite Pre-Incubator and Incubator programs—to equip Iraqi entrepreneurs with the tools, knowledge, and skills to build more resilient, efficient, and future-proof businesses.

Rather than creating standalone "climate modules," we integrated business efficiency, risk management, and value-aligned leadership principles throughout the existing curriculum. This approach ensures entrepreneurs view these topics as core business concepts rather than optional add-ons.

Modules Enhanced

24

Across both programs

New Slides Adapted

54+

New material integrated

Tools Created

5

Practical assessment frameworks

Integration Approach

Our approach focused on four key principles to ensure the changes would create tangible business value rather than just theoretical climate knowledge:

1

Business-First Framework

We framed sustainability concepts in business terms—focusing on cost savings, operational efficiency, and competitive advantages. Rather than emphasizing environmental impact, we highlighted how resource optimization directly improves business performance and profitability.

2

Risk & Resilience Integration

We incorporated risk assessment tools that help entrepreneurs identify resource vulnerabilities, supply chain disruptions, and market shifts. These tools enable businesses to develop mitigation strategies that improve long-term viability.

Example: The Risk Category Worksheet helps entrepreneurs quantify business risks related to resource costs, supply security, and market changes, then prioritize actions based on potential business impact.
3

Practical Tools & Frameworks

We created concrete, actionable tools that entrepreneurs can immediately apply to their businesses, focusing on measurable improvements rather than abstract concepts.

Example: The Business Efficiency Workbook provides structured assessments for identifying cost-saving opportunities in energy use, materials, water, transportation, and supply chain management.
4

Values-Driven Leadership

We expanded the curriculum to show how aligning business operations with core values can create stronger market differentiation, customer loyalty, and employee engagement—creating additional pathways to business success beyond traditional models.

Example: In the Business Ethics module, we added frameworks for measuring impact across the triple bottom line (People, Planet, Profit) while maintaining a focus on viable business models.

Explore the Curriculum Enhancements

Ignite Pre-Incubator Enhancements Incubator Program Enhancements New Tools & Frameworks
📊

Business Efficiency Focus

Rather than adding climate-specific content, we integrated practical efficiency concepts throughout the curriculum. For example, in the Cost Model module, we added ROI calculations for resource efficiency investments like solar panels and LED lighting.

This approach ensures entrepreneurs see resource optimization as a core business strategy rather than an environmental add-on.

🔄

Iraqi Context & Examples

We incorporated locally relevant examples like:

  • Al-Eiz Takeaway Kitchen in Qaim as a resource-efficient business model
  • UNDP Accelerator Lab's prototyping approach in Iraq
  • Iraq Central Bank's green financing initiatives

These examples demonstrate how efficiency principles apply in the local business environment.

🛠️

New Worksheets & Tools

We developed practical tools that entrepreneurs can immediately apply:

  • Business Efficiency Workbook
  • Risk Assessment Process Worksheet
  • Business Viability Matrix
  • Extreme User Interview Framework
  • Green Funding Opportunities Guide

These tools translate concepts into actionable business improvements.

© 2025 Five One Labs - Climate Connect: Entrepreneurial Resilience & Action

Funded by: IOM's WASL Civil Society Fund under the Climate Action for Resilience and Sustainability (CARS) initiative
