attachments.extracted_content:
BUILDING A BRAND
----
Agenda
----
9:00 | Settle in
9:15 | Your brand
9:35 | Unique value proposition
10:35 | Break
10:50 | Mission and values
11:45 - 12:00 | Wrap up
----


9:00 Settle in
Tea/coffee
Check in, give updates, news, and answer questions 
Go around the room and share progress of entrepreneurs
Answer any questions about the pitch or feasibility study

9:15 Begin the session
Today during our last session, we are going to talk about building a brand. 
Todays session will be high level, so we aren’t talking about branding and marketing materials, but rather who you are in your customers eyes. Once that fundamental point is clear, then you can create all that other material to help you visualize your brand.
1

SESSION OBJECTIVES:
Understand how to use your brand to communicate.

Define your unique value proposition.

Write mission and vision statements for your brand. 
1 minute: Objectives
Understand how to use your brand to communicate: You’ve gathered all this information, now we are going to try and define our business in a way that will resonate with your customer base.
Define your unique value proposition: Pinpoint the key area of your business that makes you unique.
Write your mission and vision statements for your business:  This is to have a clear written mission that is aligned with your brand. 

2

YOUR BRAND
5 minutes: Discussion

Ask: What are the different elements of a brand? What defines a brand? What do you think of when we talk about a brand?
Potential answers:
Creative elements (logo, colors, marketing, etc…)
Big companies
Consistency
The name of the market or product
The image that comes to mind when people interact with your brand
Good quality, (or bad quality)
Unique
Has creative elements (logo, name, color or font scheme, etc…)
A company’s environmental and social commitments
How responsible or sustainable a brand is perceived to be
 Follow-up Question: How do you see sustainability influencing customer perceptions of a brand?

Summary: A brand is more than just visuals; it is the overall perception customers have, shaped by consistency, quality, and increasingly, sustainability. Businesses that integrate environmental and social responsibility into their brand often attract conscious consumers and enhance their competitiveness.
3

“A brand is defined by a customers overall perception of your business.”
WHAT IS THIS?
8 minutes: Discussion

Ask: What does this apple mean? 
Potential answers:
High quality
Professional
High tech
International
Intelligence
Innovation
Steve Jobs
I phone
IOS
Expensive
Mobile phones + other products like computers and tablets
Fun or games
Sneaky or annoying sometimes 
Money driven company
Security
Trustworthy

Summary: I showed you a picture of an apple, and so much came to your mind. You mentioned the products that Apple has, their founder, that they are expensive, you all have stories about this brand and feeling around it. I can show this picture to people all around the world, and there will probably be a similar response. That is a strong brand! 

Ask: Why is having a strong brand so important?
Potential answers:
It is the identity of your business
It is how you will be remembered
You want a good brand identity, not a bad one!
Maintaining a positive brand image is important because it will have a lasting impression on customers! They don’t forget easily and they have power!
You can sell a brand, not only a product
The strategy and actions of a business could be good or bad. These actions will define your brand and will make an impact over the next several years.

Recap: Having a brand is really important for a business. It helps customers differentiate you from the competitors and remember you for what you are good at. What do we want our customers to think about when they interact with our products?



WHAT IS A BRAND?
Quality
Products and services
Creative elements
Message
A brand is consistent in its:
5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

Ask: What is a brand
Let people answer freely, then cover these points below as well: 
Quality: iPhones are great quality. We know this because it is consistently true. I would never buy an iPhone and question the quality of it. It is the same in every box in every country (unless it is a fake product). 
Products and services: Apple is consistent in their products and services as well. They are a technology company. I know that they won’t be coming out with furniture or kitchenware. That would make for a very confusing brand. When creating a brand, make sure you are consistent in the things you offer as well.
Creative elements: Commercials, marketing materials, office layout, website, Facebook, and more! Everything is in line with the same creative elements. There is a consistency with color and font schemes. Logos use and all creative elements are consistent. 
You saw the Apple logo and knew what it was immediately. If someone took another icon of a fruit with a bite in it, many of us will think of Apple. That is a strong brand! 
Message: Your message is consistent across all channels, internally, and externally. Whether it is your commercials, the writing on your packaging, blogs that you write, your company culture, or anything else, your message is clear and consistent. What is the problem you are solving? What does your business do? Make sure those things are clear.

Recap: Apply your branding across your business and evolve it as you grow. As you grow and expand, you want to make it as easy as possible for people to know exactly what you do. If you do too much, or aren’t consistent in these points, you make it hard for people to recognize you out of the crowd.

5 minutes: Brief activity
For each of the logos, discuss if they have a good brand or not. Try to touch on all of the four points mentioned on the slide.

UNIQUE VALUE PROPOSITION
5 minutes: Discussion

What is a unique value proposition?
Potential answers could be:
Something that makes you unique
A clear statement to describe what you do
The key offerings of your business
It is the point that differentiates you from your competitors
Shows why your product is better than other in the market

6

“A value proposition is a promise of value to be delivered. It’s the primary reason a prospect should buy from you”
UNIQUE VALUE PROPOSITION:
5 minutes: Discussion + lecture

State the definition of a value proposition and connect it to their ideas from before.
Ask: 
 How can we actually get to our unique value proposition? Does anyone have an idea? (What makes you stand out—whether it’s pricing, durability, or an extra benefit like helping customers save resources?) - The answers here will frame the next slides.
Potential answers:
We get it from our research
Users have to tell us
We have to look at what is already in the market
Look at competitors to see what they are offering and what they are good at
We look at our business idea and what we are good at
We consider whether sustainability can be a unique differentiator (e.g., eco-friendly materials, ethical supply chains, low-carbon operations, waste reduction).
 
 Discussion Prompt: Could sustainability be a part of your Unique Value Proposition? If yes, how?

Recap: Over the past month, you guys have been doing a ton of research. You have done a deep dive into the market to try to identify gaps and areas of opportunity. You now know 3 important factors needed to define our UVP:
What you and your business are good at
What the market wants and needs
What competitors are offering
 Additional Consideration: Some businesses differentiate themselves by being the "green alternative." Think about how sustainability could enhance your value proposition.

Your business 
and what you 
do well
The market 
and customers needs 
5 minutes: Lecture

So first there is you. You all came in here with business ideas and you want to see if there is a market for it. You have certain:
Capabilities
Interests
Information
A business idea 
Skills
Experience

But you also have the market. The market has:
People with changing needs, wants, desires, frustrations, etc…
The market can be big or small
Your market is where you can actually reach, so it can be limited geographically
Etc…

What we are searching for this month, is to see if people want your idea. Based on your capabilities of developing and delivering a product, will people want what you have? And the next question, is there enough people who want it? 
Through the animation of the circles, show:
The more overlap between your business idea and the needs of the market means that there is more potential for your business to succeed. 
When there is a small overlap (a small number of people in the market interested in your idea), there is a smaller market potential. This could be considered a niche market.
Make sure the size of the market is worth your time and energy! Ask yourself, “is this enough for me? Will I be satisfied from the returns of this market?”

Your business 
and what you
do well
The market 
and customers
needs
Competitors
UNIQUE 
VALUE PROPOSITION
5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

But there is one more thing. The market also has something else, competitors! They:
Sell other things similar to yours
Serving your customers needs now!
Don’t serve the needs of the whole market 
You won’t ever have the whole market

Because not everyone's needs are being met. There is an opportunity to meet those customers needs and differentiate yourself from your competitors. 

Ask: Based on this visual, where should you focus your energy?
Overlap between competitors and you: Don’t go here! The market doesn’t show any desire for these things! Don’t waste your energy or time.
Overlap between competitors and market: You could try to go here, but it could be dangerous. You are competing with your competitors on something they are really good at, and you are not good at. You might be seen as a less desirable option to your customers. Or it will take some time to be a strong competitor.
Overlap between the three circles: This is somehow the bare minimum. Customers want it, competitors do it, and you have the capabilities for it. You should probably be doing this too. 
Overlap between you and the market: This is where you will find your unique value proposition. Customers want it, but the competitors aren’t offering it! Here is where you can really add value and differentiate yourself from your competitors.

Why choose you?

WHERE DO YOU CREATE UNIQUE VALUE?
Cheaper price?
Faster service?
Higher quality?
10 minutes: Discussion + Activity

Ask: Keeping what we just talked about in mind, what are your value propositions? What is the promise of value you will deliver to your customers? The primary reason customers buy from you instead of your competitor?
Take some time to think about the UVP, then have everyone share their answers.
Trainer note: Make sure they are not just explaining their product, listing features, or creating a slogan.

Other examples you can bring up if needed:
Nike offers four primary value propositions: accessibility, innovation, customization, and brand/status (https://www.cleverism.com/company/nike/).
The value proposition of MailChimp that they offer is simple, direct, and bold.
Apple's Iphone value proposition, offers a unique experience
Uber's value proposition, offers uber convenience (https://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2016/04/27/value-proposition-examples)
10

POSITIONING STATEMENT TEMPLATE:
(Target Personas)
(Product Name)
(Category)
(Key Customer Benefit)
(Nearest Competitive Alternatives)
Is the one
that
unlike
TO
5 minutes: Activity

5 minutes: Explanation of Positioning statement and difference from UVP
Your Positioning statement is a way to take your UVP and engage your customers. You are speaking to them in this statement. 
The UVP and positioning statements are rooted in a clear understanding of your customers and what drives them emotionally
A UVP shows what differentiates your product from your competitors’ products/services and makes it special.
Your positioning statement captures the space you want to own in your customer’s mind, based on the unique value that you can offer.
If sustainability is a part of your business model, your positioning statement can reflect that.
 Trainer Notes:
 Encourage participants to think about whether sustainability could be a key differentiator in their positioning.
 Sustainability-driven positioning can help businesses attract customers who prioritize eco-friendly products and responsible brands.


TO all global travelers, (Tourism App) is the one digital platform that builds the ideal travel experience based on your needs unlike any other tourism option.
10 minutes: Activity

Go over the example on the board, then let everyone practice
Example: Tourism application
UVP: Convenient and customizable 
Positioning Statement: To all global travelers, Tourism App is the one digital platform that builds the ideal travel experience based on your needs unlike any other tourism option.

Everyone should create their positioning statement.
1-2 people to share if they want

12

MISSION & VALUES
10 minutes: Discussion

Mission, vision, and values
So, what are mission, vision, and value statements? What is the difference between them? 
Write out their thoughts on the board separating mission and values
Mission statement: A Mission statement describes why the organization exists and why it does what it does.
Usually is bigger than the organization itself
Many times mission is “unrealistic”
Can also reflect environmental and social commitments (e.g., Patagonia’s mission: “We’re in business to save our home planet”).

Value statement: A value statement describes and lists the fundamental values and principles that the organization operates by.
Company focused
Where you hope to see the business down the line
Product related
Can highlight sustainability commitments (e.g., responsible sourcing, reducing waste, ethical labor practices).

Entrepreneurs might bring up vision statements as well. A vision statement describes the ideal future state of the organization.  It articulates what the organization is trying to accomplish.

Ask: Why is it important to have clearly defined mission, vision, and value statements? (Customers care about consistency, trust, and whether a business is ethical, efficient, or innovative.)
Have a discussion and write down all the thoughts on the board.
Potential answers:
Stay focused on what is really important,
Businesses should be able to clearly talk about what they are trying to achieve (on a grander scale),
They should have a statement to show why they exist,
Having a clear statement provides direction for employees and management, 
Keeps businesses accountable for their environmental and social impact.
Helps brands build long-term customer loyalty by aligning with sustainability values.
Keeps your business customer/solution oriented instead of just focusing on profits,
Communicate the company’s beliefs to employees, customers, partners, and the general public,
Establish an identity, start a corporate culture,
Attract like-minded employees,
Aid in the decision-making process (use the mission to reflect on the companies greater goals),
Keeps you thinking about the future (great leaders/organizations always are)!

13

“We create happiness by providing the finest in entertainment for people of all ages, everywhere”
“To organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful”
“Simplify life for people around the world”
MISSION STATEMENTS:
“We are synergizing green power and cloud computing technologies to build alternative energy projects and generate new revenues.”
20 minutes: Discussion + activity

8 minutes: Mission statements
Ask: Take a look at these famous company mission statements. What do you see among all of them? 
Potential answers:
Many people might reiterate some points from before
None of these missions state the products/services they sell
It is the end goal for the customers
They fulfill their “why”, their purpose, through their products and services

10-15 minutes: Activity
Write your mission! So, what is it that you want to accomplish? Don’t think about money, don’t think about sustainable answers, or anything else. If you could see a change in the world, what would that look like?
Have a few people read out their missions if they want to

Other examples of mission statements:
Amazon's mission hints at its world-ruling ambitions: "It's our goal to be Earth's most customer-centric company, where customers can find and discover anything online.“
Facebook's mission is to give people the power to share and make the world more open and connected.“
Uber has a simple, bold, mission: "Transportation as reliable as running water, everywhere for everyone.“
Twitter's mission is "To give everyone the power to create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.“
Dropbox’s mission is to “simplify life for people around the world."
14

DETERMINE YOUR CORE VALUES:
Innovation
Teamwork
Commitment
15 minutes: Activity

Activity: What do you value?
Give out the list of verbs
Each entrepreneur should take about 5 minutes to choose all of the verbs that represent their business,
Go around the room and ask how many people have circled
Some people will have few values chosen which shows that they might have a clear picture and a focus already
Some people might have chosen almost all of them. In this case, point out that it is great to have so many values; however, it is hard for one business to represent them all.
Give the entrepreneurs 3 more minutes to choose only five.
 5 minutes: Add a verb to each
Examples: Live adventurously, create curiosity, build independence, etc…

Multiply, promote, act, find, search for, establish, think, listen, laugh, hold, encourage, have, be, practice, unite, 

Questions that might come up:
Should I pick my values or company values? As the founder of your company, your values should be intertwined with your company values to a degree. The leadership of your company should embody the mission and values your company projects to the world. 
Can this change? Yes it can change; however, try to think of long lasting values that will help shape your company and its culture. These values should last far into the future. If these values are not in line with your customers and their needs, you might face problems. 
15

DETERMINE YOUR CORE VALUES:
Integrity
Responsibility
Sustainability
15 minutes: Activity

Activity: What do you value?
Give out the list of verbs
Each entrepreneur should take about 5 minutes to choose all of the verbs that represent their business,
Go around the room and ask how many people have circled
Some people will have few values chosen which shows that they might have a clear picture and a focus already
Some people might have chosen almost all of them. In this case, point out that it is great to have so many values; however, it is hard for one business to represent them all.
Give the entrepreneurs 3 more minutes to choose only five.
 5 minutes: Add a verb to each
Examples: Live adventurously, create curiosity, build independence, etc…

Multiply, promote, act, find, search for, establish, think, listen, laugh, hold, encourage, have, be, practice, unite, 

Questions that might come up:
Should I pick my values or company values? As the founder of your company, your values should be intertwined with your company values to a degree. The leadership of your company should embody the mission and values your company projects to the world. 
Can this change? Yes it can change; however, try to think of long lasting values that will help shape your company and its culture. These values should last far into the future. If these values are not in line with your customers and their needs, you might face problems. 
16

Creating a culture of warmth and belonging, where everyone is welcome.
Acting with courage, challenging the status quo.
Being present, connecting with transparency, dignity and respect.
We are performance driven, through the lens of humanity.

“To inspire and nurture the human spirit- one person, one cup, and one neighborhood at a time ”
STARBUCKS
10 minutes: Discussion

Starbucks example:
Let’s take a look at Starbucks mission and value statements. 
How do they live by these statements?
Is this something that is just written in their documents, or do they live by this?
17

Refine your brand positioning statement based on your unique value proposition. 
Refine your mission and vision statements for your brand.
BUILD YOUR BUSINESS
18

THANK YOU!
Any Questions?

messages.content:
I'll help you refine Session 8 (Building a Brand) to better integrate your green approach, focusing on values as sources of meaning rather than just a word list exercise. This aligns with Joe Edelman's perspective that values should be rooted in what creates meaningful experiences for people.

## Overall Approach Recommendations

The current "Building a Brand" session uses a standard corporate approach to values (selecting words from a list), which doesn't create the deep connection to meaning that drives authentic action. Here's how we can transform it:

### 1. Shift from Values as Words to Values as Sources of Meaning

The current approach asks entrepreneurs to select value words from a list, which often results in generic corporate values (integrity, innovation, etc.) that don't necessarily guide authentic action or connect deeply with customers.

**Recommended Change:** 
- Replace the value word selection exercise with a meaning-based exploration
- Focus on identifying situations where entrepreneurs and their potential customers experience what matters most to them
- Connect these meaningful experiences to the business's potential positive impact

### 2. Connect Values to the Business Efficiency Framework

Your green integration approach focuses on practical business benefits rather than abstract environmental messaging. We should maintain this focus.

**Recommended Change:**
- Show how values alignment creates business efficiency (reduced customer acquisition costs, stronger loyalty, better employee retention)
- Demonstrate how values-driven businesses can reduce risks by attracting more stable customer relationships
- Emphasize the competitive advantage of authentic values alignment

## Specific Slide Improvements

### Slide 2: YOUR BRAND (Discussion Slide)

**Current:** Basic discussion about brand elements

**Improved Version:**
```
YOUR BRAND

5 minutes: Discussion

Ask: What defines a truly meaningful brand? What brands do you personally connect with and why?

Potential answers:
- Brands that solve real problems in my life
- Brands that share my values about what matters
- Brands that help me live better according to what I care about
- Brands that are transparent and authentic
- Brands that help me be more efficient with resources
- Brands that respect my values and priorities

Follow-up Question: How do these meaningful connections create business advantages like customer loyalty and word-of-mouth marketing?

Summary: A brand is more than logo and visuals—it's a relationship based on shared values and meaningful experiences. When customers connect with your brand on a values level, they become advocates, reducing marketing costs and building resilience against market shifts.
```

### Slide 11-12: MISSION & VALUES (Discussion Slide)

**Current:** Conventional mission/values discussion with some green elements

**Improved Version:**
```
MISSION & VALUES: SOURCES OF MEANING

10 minutes: Discussion

Ask: What makes work meaningful for you personally? When have you felt most fulfilled in your work?

Facilitator notes:
- Guide discussion toward meaningful experiences, not abstract concepts
- Encourage examples of when entrepreneurs felt their work mattered
- Connect these meaningful experiences to potential customer experiences

Key Discussion Points:
- Mission as shared purpose: What meaningful difference are you and your customers trying to make together?
- Values as sources of meaning: What situations create meaningful experiences for you and your customers?
- Authenticity matters: Customers can detect when values are just marketing vs. truly lived

Examples:
- Patagonia's mission isn't "sustainability" (an abstract word), but "We're in business to save our home planet" (a meaningful purpose)
- Their values show up in repair services and "Don't Buy This Jacket" campaigns
- This creates business advantages: lower marketing costs, higher customer loyalty, resilience to price competition
```

### Slides 14-15: DETERMINE YOUR CORE VALUES (Activity)

**Current:** Selection from a values word list

**Improved Value Discovery Exercise:**
```
DISCOVER YOUR MEANINGFUL VALUES

20 minutes: Activity

Introduction: "Instead of selecting abstract value words, let's discover what truly creates meaning for you and your customers."

Step 1: Meaningful Moments (5 min)
- Write down 2-3 moments when you felt your work was truly meaningful
- What made these moments matter to you?

Step 2: Customer Meaning (5 min)
- Based on your research, when do your customers experience meaningful moments related to your product/service?
- What conditions or situations create meaning for them?

Step 3: Business Advantages (5 min)
- How could aligning with these sources of meaning:
  * Reduce your marketing costs?
  * Strengthen customer loyalty?
  * Differentiate you from competitors?
  * Create operational efficiencies?

Step 4: Express Your Values (5 min)
- Create value statements that express the conditions that create meaning
- Example: "We create opportunities for families to connect through shared outdoor experiences" (vs. generic "Family" or "Connection")
```

### New Slide: VALUES-DRIVEN BUSINESS ADVANTAGES

```
VALUES-DRIVEN BUSINESS ADVANTAGES

5 minutes: Discussion

Explain: "When values are authentic sources of meaning, they create concrete business benefits:"

1. Lower Customer Acquisition Costs
   - Customers who share your values become advocates
   - Word-of-mouth reduces marketing expenses

2. Operational Efficiencies
   - Values alignment reduces waste (doing only what matters)
   - Staff motivated by meaningful work are more productive

3. Business Resilience
   - Values-aligned customers are less price-sensitive
   - Meaningful connections survive market disruptions

4. Resource Optimization
   - Focus on what truly creates meaning often requires fewer resources
   - Eliminating meaningless activities reduces waste

Example: Patagonia's Worn Wear program repairs old clothing instead of selling new items - seems counterintuitive, but creates stronger customer loyalty and reduces marketing costs
```

## Updated Positioning Statement Worksheet

Here's an improved version of your positioning statement worksheet that integrates the values-as-meaning approach:

```
**Positioning Statement Worksheet**

A positioning statement shows how your product/service creates meaningful value for your customers in a way that's different from competitors. Today we'll create a positioning that reflects both what you offer and the meaningful experiences you create.

**PART 1: MEANINGFUL VALUE DISCOVERY**

What meaningful experiences do your customers seek? 
_________________________________________________

What barriers prevent them from having these experiences?
_________________________________________________

How does your business enable these meaningful experiences?
_________________________________________________

**PART 2: UNIQUE VALUE PROPOSITION**

The unique value you provide (functional + meaningful):
_________________________________________________

**PART 3: POSITIONING STATEMENT TEMPLATE**

To: ____________(TARGET PERSONAS)_______________, 
          _____________**(PRODUCT NAME)**_________________ is the one
          _______________(CATEGORY)____________________that
          __________(KEY CUSTOMER BENEFIT)____________ unlike
          _____(NEAREST COMPETITIVE ALTERNATIVE)______

**EXAMPLE:**

TO environmentally conscious travelers, **(EcoJourney App)** is the one travel planning platform that connects you with authentic local experiences while minimizing environmental impact, unlike standard tourism platforms that prioritize mass tourism regardless of its effects.

**YOUR STATEMENT:**
_________________________________________________
_________________________________________________

**PART 4: YOUR MISSION STATEMENT**
(What meaningful difference are you and your customers making together?)
_________________________________________________
_________________________________________________

**PART 5: YOUR VALUE STATEMENTS**
(Describe situations that create meaning for you and your customers)

1. _________________________________________________
2. _________________________________________________
3. _________________________________________________
4. _________________________________________________
5. _________________________________________________
```

This approach will help participants develop authentic, meaningful brand positions that naturally integrate efficiency and resource optimization as pathways to creating value, rather than treating sustainability as a separate "green" add-on. It aligns perfectly with your business-first approach to climate integration.

            * ** How can we actually get to our unique value proposition? Does anyone have an idea? (What makes you stand out—whether it’s pricing, durability, or an extra benefit like helping customers save resources?) The answers here will frame the next slides.**
            * **Potential answers:**
               * **We get it from our research**
               * **Users have to tell us**
               * **We have to look at what is already in the market**
               * **Look at competitors to see what they are offering and what they are good at**
               * **We look at our business idea and what we are good at**
               * **We consider whether sustainability can be a unique differentiator (e.g., eco-friendly materials, ethical supply chains, low-carbon operations, waste reduction).**
** **
         * ** Discussion Prompt: Could sustainability be a part of your Unique Value Proposition? If yes, how?**
         * **Recap: Over the past month, you guys have been doing a ton of research. You have done a deep dive into the market to try to identify gaps and areas of opportunity. You now know 3 important factors needed to define our UVP:**
            * **What you and your business are good at**
            * **What the market wants and needs**
            * **What competitors are offering**
         * ** Additional Consideration: Some businesses differentiate themselves by being the "green alternative." Think about how sustainability could enhance your value proposition.]]]**
   * I sort of imagine that we might need to shift things around potentially to have it flow right. how do we keep things busienss related while also updating the values exploration to be true and sincere without disconecting from the business articulation value of a UVP etc?

UPDATED COPY OF BUSINESS ETHICS
BUSINESS ETHICS
----
Agenda
----
9:00 | Settle in
9:15 | Business Ethics and sustainability
9:45 | Triple bottom line
10:10 | Break
10:25 | Define your impact
11:40 - 12:00 | Wrap up
----
9:00 | Settle in
Tea/coffee
Answer entrepreneur questions related to their prototypes, the pitch or anything else.
9:15 | Begin the session
Good morning everyone! How are you doing today?
Today, we will talk about business ethics and how to incorporate ethics and sustainability
into your business model.
1
Establish a clear understanding of what business ethics is.
Identify why & how to integrate triple bottom line thinking (People, Planet, and Profit)
into a business model.
Formulate a plan to build resilience and measure impact.
1 minute: Objectives
Establish a clear understanding of what business ethics is.
Identify ways to include the triple bottom line into your business model
Formulate a plan to create and measure impact.
2
WHAT ARE ETHICS?
15 Minutes: Discussion - Ethics: Living Values That Ignite Business
Kickoff (2-3 minutes):
"Let's discuss ethics as a foundation for aligning your business with authenticity,
purpose, and resilience. Ethics aren’t just rules to follow—they represent your deeper
'why' and drive your business forward, especially in challenging times.
"
Discussion Questions (10 minutes):
When someone says 'ethics,
' what's the first thing that comes to your mind?
How can authenticity provide your business with unique advantages that competitors
can't easily replicate?
What impact does alignment with a founder's deepest values have on business
success?
Can you recall a moment when you felt genuinely alive and motivated by your work?
How can that kind of energy enhance business performance?
Have you seen examples where businesses succeeded specifically because they stayed
true to their core values? What happened?
Who are the stakeholders impacted by your business (customers, employees, local
community, environment)? Why does considering their well-being contribute to your
long-term success?
Encourage participants to share real examples—situations where businesses either lost
trust by cutting corners or built loyalty by sticking firmly to their values.
As the conversation progresses, highlight the two fundamental approaches to ethics:
Wrap-Up Points (2-3 minutes):
"We've talked about two main pathways businesses can take regarding
ethics—Compliance-based and Values-based. Let's briefly explore each:"
Compliance-Based Ethics: Playing Safe
Doing what's legally required—meeting regulations and avoiding penalties.
Primarily focused on avoiding problems and doing no harm.
Limitations: Laws differ by location, and simply following rules doesn't create deeper
connections with customers or employees.
Values-Based Ethics: Igniting Purpose
Going beyond compliance because you have a meaningful purpose and clear core
values.
Acting authentically, proactively, and ethically—even when nobody is
watching—because your 'why' genuinely drives you.
Willingness to put in extra effort aligned with your values, making your work more
purposeful and fulfilling.
Why Values Ignite Your Business:
Customer Connection: People support businesses whose values align with theirs.
Authenticity builds trust, loyalty, and lasting customer relationships.
Team Loyalty: Employees remain engaged and motivated when their work serves a
meaningful purpose beyond financial compensation.
Long-term Resilience: Businesses guided by strong, clear values can more effectively
adapt to challenges and thrive amid uncertainty.
Competitive Edge: Authenticity differentiates your business clearly and powerfully in
crowded markets.
Closing Thought:
We aren't just building startups—we're cultivating purpose-driven businesses that attract
customers, inspire communities, and stand the test of time. Ethics, grounded in
authenticity and values, can become your a strategic advantage.
As Epictetus famously said:
"First say to yourself what you would be; and then do what you have to.
"
3
5 Minutes: Discussion - Ethics: Living Values That Ignite Business Continued
Discussion Questions (2-3 minutes):
What is your strong why? What “why” will keep you going when things are hard? What
values and ethical ways of doing business will inspire you, help you find aligned funders,
team members and customers?
4
3-5 minutes: Discussion:
Ask: What do you think about this video? How do you think it was received by the
public?
3 minutes: Lecture
Share some actual figures about this video:
$101,000 budget to make the video
+$150,000,000 in returns
3x more views than some Super Bowl commercials
This video caused the largest traffic spike to their website
Their story was featured all over the news and on shows like Ellen.
5
“Brands with a purpose grow faster”
UNILEVER STRATEGY
5 minutes: Lecture
Unilever is the +$62.6 billion/yr company that owns Dove and many other international
brands.
After researching, they discovered with bottom line evidence that “Brands with a purpose
grow faster” (twice as fast for some of their companies). Their internal data showed that
15% of growth came from brands that had a purpose. Therefore, they made a strategic
decision to adjust their strategy to make sure that all of their brands have an activated
brand purpose.
“The cost of inaction is a lot more than taking action”
- Jonathan Atwood VP of
communications and sustainable living at Unlilever.
Short discussion: Can you think of a business you interact with because you align with
their values and purpose?
6
McDonalds, Green and Healthy?
3-5 minutes: Discuss
Is McDonald's known to be a green and healthy restaurant?
Why did McDonalds go “green” in Europe?
Is this an authentic display of McDonald’s core values? Why or why not?
7
FROM WORDS TO PURPOSE
Innovation
Teamwork
Commitment
Integrity
Responsibility
Facilitator Notes (1-2 minutes):
Open with challenge: "Every business claims values like these on their website. But
when do these words actually matter? What makes the difference between empty
statements and values that guide real decisions?"
Quick example: McDonald's painted arches green and added salads, claiming
environmental values—but their core business remains unchanged"
Go To Slide 10
8
Company
Claimed Values
Actual Practices
🚫 McDonald's
Sustainability, Health
Minimal menu changes; superficial “green” initiatives; continues to rely heavily on
unhealthy, highly processed foods.
🚫 Volkswagen (Dieselgate)
Integrity, Responsibility
Lied about emissions software, lost public trust and environmental claims.
✅ Patagonia
Sustainability, Responsibility
Transparent supply chain; promotes repair over replacement; donates profits to
environmental protection.
✅ Tony’s Chocolonely
Fairness, Integrity
Actively combats slavery in chocolate industry; transparent about challenges and
solutions.
FROM WORDS TO PURPOSE
Facilitator Notes (2-3 minutes):
Discuss: "Think about your stated values. What would it look like if these weren't just
words but the heartbeat of your business? What would your customers notice and miss if
you were gone tomorrow?"
Bridge to next slide: "Your values matter only when they guide real choices and actions.
Things people can see, hear, share. Actions that connect with people, profit, and
planet—what we call the triple bottom line. That's where we're headed next.
"
9
WHO ARE YOUR STAKEHOLDERS?
PEOPLE
PLANET
PROFIT
2-3 minutes: Lecture
As a business, you will have an impact on so many different people just by existing. You
have an impact on your customers, your employees, the shareholders of your company,
the communities you operate in, and the planet we live on. This impact could be positive
or negative and it all depends on the choices you make as the leader of your company.
Therefore, you should actively think through how your business decisions will impact all
of your different stakeholders.
We will look at the triple bottom line business model to do this. When you think of a
“bottom line”
, traditionally that means a solely profit driven business (bottom line of a
P&L), but there are businesses who are driven for other reasons as well (people driven
companies, environmentally driven companies, etc…)
Over the next few slides, spend time in each category to brainstorm things entrepreneurs
can do right now or in the near future to be more ethical and ultimately, more sustainable
in these 3 categories (representing the Triple Bottom Line model):
People
Planet
Profit
Trainer tip: Over the next few slides, try to avoid answers such as “make donations” or
“give away free products”
. Those things are great, but try to get the entrepreneurs to
think about how their core of their business’ existence can be rooted in uplifting the
world. Donations and giveaways are great, but they aren’t sustainable on their own. We
will discuss “good answers” on the next slides. These things can include using less
plastic in packaging, having a transparent and fair hiring process, etc…).
10
PEOPLE
5-10 minutes: Discussion
Have a discussion on ways to positively impact all the people who interact with your
business or are impacted by it in some way.
Write all the answers on the board.
As people share answers, try to go deeper and show how these “ethical” actions actually
have a positive impact on your business as well
Ask: What are things that your business can do to have a positive impact on people?
Potential answers:
Community:
Educational events and workshops related to your mission for community members,
customers, employees, etc…
Partnerships and collaborations with other businesses or organizations working towards
the same mission
Hire from your local community. Job creation stimulates growth.
Hire vulnerable or marginalized people
Tackle social issues through company policy and actions
Employees:
Pay employees well
Give employees benefits
Provide education or personal development opportunities
Ensure fair (or good) hours and working conditions
Customers:
Your business should be solving a problem for them
Your products should be safe and not cause any harm
Listen and respect them
Examples you can give:
Chobani Yogurt has a policy to hire refugees which positively affects society
Starbucks has a policy to hire veterans and refugees. They also have policies to prevent
food waste and give food to people in need within their communities.
Trainer tip: If entrepreneurs are having a hard time coming up with answers, consider
asking “What are some ethical companies you know about? How do they treat their
employees and community? What do they do that inspires you?
11
PROFIT
5 minutes: Discussion
In the triple bottom line model, profits are important, but not always the driving force. At
the end of the day, you have to remember that you have to make a profit. It is great to do
good, but if you can’t sustain yourself your business won’t last.
Ask: How can you actually implement some of those ideas from before while also
keeping profitability in mind?
Potential answers:
Conduct a cost benefit analysis on the ideas to see which owns are most “beneficial”
Only do things that you can afford to do
Find other companies or organizations to donate to your cause and
Integrate ethics into your business model in a way that ethical behavior is always
profitable!
Etc…
More information on the examples you from the “People slide”:
Chobani Yogurt has a policy to hire refugees which positively affects society (this does
not affect profits at all)
Starbucks has a policy to hire veterans and refugees. They also have policies to prevent
food waste and give food to people in need within their communities. (these decisions
have actually had a positive effect on Starbucks profitability from the good publicity)
12
PLANET
5-10 minutes: Discussion
Have a discussion on ways to positively impact all the environment and planet with your
business.
Write all the answers on the board.
As people share answers, try to go deeper and show how these “ethical” actions actually
have a positive impact on your business as well
Ask: What are things that your business can do to have a positive impact on the planet?
Potential answers:
Consider circular business models that use a different way of producing and consuming
goods to be more environmentally friendly and “circular” (in a way that mimics natures).
This can include using recycled materials in production or incentivizing customers to
return products to the company where it can be refurbished or reused in another way
(circular model). Avoid extracting things from the earth, giving it to the customers, and
putting it in a landfill (this is a linear model).
Recycle when you can
Reduce consumption and try to conserve natural resources
Reuse when you can instead of creating more waste
Repair old or broken materials instead of throwing them out
Donate excess materials/goods instead of throwing them out
Streamline processes and remove unnecessary steps
Think of ways to have a better impact on water & air quality,
Trainer tip: If entrepreneurs are having a hard time coming up with answers, consider
asking “What are some ethical companies you know about? What do they do to
positively impact the environment? What do they do that inspires you?
13
LIVING YOUR VALUES, NOT JUST MARKETING THEM
Facilitator Notes (5 minutes: Discussion)
"We've talked about finding values that truly matter to you and activating them through
the triple bottom line. But in a world where 'ethical' and 'green' have become marketing
buzzwords, how do businesses that genuinely live their values stand out from those just
wearing the costume?"
Transition: This disconnect between what companies claim and what they do has a
name: 'greenwashing' or 'ethics washing.
' It happens when values become marketing
tools rather than authentic guides for decisions.
Ask: "How can your business demonstrate that your values run deeper than marketing?
How do you build trust that your 'why' is genuine?"
Guide toward concrete answers:
"Make choices that might cost you something in the short term but align with your
values"
"Be transparent about both your successes and challenges"
"Invite verification through certification programs relevant to your sector:"
ISO standards for quality and environmental management
Organic certification for food products
Fair Trade for ethical supply chains
B Corporation certification for overall social and environmental performance
Connect back to meaning: The strongest businesses don't just meet standards—they set
them based on what truly matters to them. When values come from an authentic source
of meaning, customers don't just see compliance—they feel your authentic purpose and
builds loyalty that marketing can't buy.
Application: Now, thinking about your specific business and the values we've been
discussing, what's one concrete action you could take this month that would
demonstrate your commitment isn't just talk?
14
FROM VALUES TO IMPACT
MEASURE WHAT MATTERS
ACTIVATING YOUR BRAND PURPOSE:
Facilitator Notes (5 minutes: Introduction & Set-Up)
Clearly connect this activity to the previous discussions:
We've talked extensively about ethics, authenticity, and avoiding greenwashing/values
washing. Now it’s time to put this into action. Real business ethics means aligning what
you say (your values) with what you actually do. Let's move beyond words and create a
concrete, measurable way to activate your brand purpose.
Guiding Questions (for entrepreneurs):
What problem are you genuinely solving?
Who benefits directly from your solution (customers, employees, community)?
Based on your authentic core values, what three meaningful impacts do you want your
business to have in the world?
Activity Instructions (1 hour):
Clearly list your core values and your deeper "why" behind your business.
Identify at least three measurable actions your business can take that authentically
embody these values and positively impact your stakeholders (People, Planet, Profit).
Describe specific ways you will measure and communicate these impacts:
Consider customer surveys, storytelling, transparency initiatives, and formal impact
reports.
Explore widely recognized third-party certifications and assessments, such as:
ISO standards
Fair Trade Certification
Organic Certification
LEED Certification
Rainforest Alliance
B Corporation Certification
Take the B Impact Assessment:
Log in or create an account at B Impact Assessment.
Work through the questions relevant to your business. It's okay if you don't know all the
answers yet—use this as a tool to identify areas where you can integrate stronger
practices and measurements aligned with your values.
Note: A score of 80 or above indicates passing, and it is a challenging benchmark!
Group Activity (15 minutes: Small Group Discussions)
Break into groups of 3-5.
Share your identified impacts, strategies, and measurement ideas.
Provide and receive feedback: Are these strategies aligned clearly with your core
mission and values? Are they realistically achievable and measurable?
Trainer Tip: Encourage entrepreneurs to focus deeply on practical and meaningful
metrics—ones that genuinely resonate with investors, customers, and stakeholders,
demonstrating authenticity beyond superficial marketing.
15
BUILD YOUR BUSINESS:
Update your mission statement (if necessary)
Finish the B Impact Assessment.
Identify 3 areas of impact that you care about and want to measure.
5 minutes: Wrap up
16
THANK YOU
ANY QUESTIONS?
5 minutes: Wrap up

# Reimagining Values-Based Brand Building

I think the key opportunity here is to create a more coherent flow that moves from meaning to values to business application, rather than treating them as separate exercises. Here's how I'd restructure and update these key sections:

## Restructured Flow

1. **Start with meaning exploration** - Begin with personal experiences that matter
2. **Connect to values** - Identify the values embedded in those meaningful experiences
3. **Translate to business purpose** - Link these authentic values to business mission
4. **Identify unique value proposition** - Show how these values create distinctive advantages

## Updated Content for Slide 14: Mission & Values

```
MISSION & VALUES: WHAT TRULY MATTERS

10 minutes: Guided Reflection & Discussion

Ask: "Think about a time when your work felt deeply meaningful to you - when you felt like what you were doing really mattered. What was happening in that moment?"

Facilitate sharing of these moments, noting common themes on the board.

Follow-up: "What made these experiences meaningful? What conditions or situations created that sense of purpose?"

Connect to Mission & Values:
- Mission is not about grand statements, but about creating the conditions for meaningful experiences
- Values are not abstract words, but the lived priorities that show up in your meaningful moments
- When your business creates these same meaningful conditions for customers, employees and communities, you build authentic connection

Examples to share:
- Patagonia's mission "We're in business to save our home planet" emerged from the founder's meaningful experiences in nature
- Their repair program came from valuing durability and reducing waste, not from selecting "sustainability" from a word list

Ask: "How might creating these meaningful conditions for others also create business advantages?"
Potential answers:
- Customers who share these values become loyal advocates
- Employees find deeper motivation beyond paychecks
- Decision-making becomes clearer and more consistent
- Resource efficiency happens naturally when you focus on what truly matters
```

## Updated Content for Slide 16: Discovering Your Core Values

```
DISCOVERING YOUR CORE VALUES

20 minutes: Facilitated Activity

Introduction: "Instead of selecting values from a list, we'll discover them in your most meaningful experiences."

Step 1: Meaningful Moments (5 min - Individual)
- Write down 2-3 specific moments when your work felt most meaningful
- What was happening? Who was involved? What made it matter?

Step 2: Identify Underlying Values (5 min - Individual)
- For each meaningful moment, ask: "What made this situation important to me?"
- What conditions or qualities were present that created meaning?
- What would someone watching notice you cared about?

Step 3: Connect to Customer Experience (5 min - Individual)
- How might your customers experience similar meaningful moments through your business?
- What conditions can your business create that would matter to them in similar ways?

Step 4: Small Group Sharing (5 min)
- Share your meaningful moments and the values you discovered
- Help each other identify authentic values you might have missed
- Discuss how these values could shape business decisions

Facilitator Notes:
- Authentic values come from lived experience, not abstract words
- The same meaning-creating conditions that matter to you will likely matter to others
- These authentic values will inform both your mission and your unique value proposition
- Values aren't just what you say, but how you make decisions when trade-offs arise
```

## Updated Content for Slide 7: Unique Value Proposition 

```
UNIQUE VALUE PROPOSITION: MEANINGFUL DIFFERENCE

10 minutes: Discussion + Exercise

A value proposition is a promise of meaningful value that your business delivers better than alternatives. It answers: "Why should people choose you?"

Ask: "How do your authentic values create a unique advantage in the market?"
Guide discussion to explore:

1. Intersection of Meaning
   - What meaningful experiences do your customers seek?
   - How do your authentic values help create those experiences?
   - What meaningful difference does your solution make compared to alternatives?

2. Business Advantages
   - Does your values-aligned approach create efficiency advantages?
   - Can your authentic values reduce costs or risks in ways competitors can't?
   - Do shared values with customers create stronger loyalty and reduce marketing costs?

Exercise:
Complete this sentence: "Unlike our competitors, we _____________ because we genuinely value _____________."

Examples to share:
- Patagonia: "Unlike typical outdoor brands, we help you keep using what you already own because we genuinely value reducing environmental impact."
- Warby Parker: "Unlike traditional eyewear companies, we make prescription glasses accessible to more people because we genuinely value equal access to vision care."
```

## Bringing It All Together: Integrated Worksheet

I'd create a single integrated worksheet that walks participants through the full journey from meaning to business value:

```
MEANINGFUL BRAND DEVELOPMENT WORKSHEET

PART 1: MEANINGFUL MOMENTS
Describe 2-3 times when your work felt truly meaningful:
1. ________________________________________________
2. ________________________________________________
3. ________________________________________________

What conditions or qualities made these experiences matter to you?
________________________________________________
________________________________________________

PART 2: AUTHENTIC VALUES
Based on your meaningful experiences, what do you genuinely value?
(Not abstract words, but the specific conditions that create meaning)
1. ________________________________________________
2. ________________________________________________
3. ________________________________________________

PART 3: MISSION STATEMENT
How does your business create these same meaningful conditions for others?
________________________________________________
________________________________________________

PART 4: UNIQUE VALUE PROPOSITION

What meaningful experiences do your customers seek?
________________________________________________

How does your business uniquely deliver these experiences?
________________________________________________

Unlike competitors, we _________________ because we genuinely value _________________.

PART 5: BUSINESS ADVANTAGES
How do your authentic values create business benefits?

Lower costs: _______________________________________
(e.g., reduced marketing costs through word-of-mouth, resource efficiency)

Reduced risks: _____________________________________
(e.g., more loyal customers, more stable supply chain)

Market differentiation: _______________________________
(e.g., clear positioning that's hard for competitors to copy)
```

## Key Integration Points

To maintain the business focus while deepening the values exploration:

1. **Frame values as business assets** - Show how authentic values create tangible business advantages (lower acquisition costs, stronger loyalty, better decision-making)

2. **Connect values to efficiency** - Demonstrate how focusing on what truly matters often leads to resource optimization (eliminating meaningless activities, focusing on essential value)

3. **Link values to risk reduction** - Explain how values alignment creates resilience (loyal customers, motivated employees, clearer decision-making in crises)

4. **Integrate values into market differentiation** - Show how authentic values create hard-to-copy competitive advantages

This approach transforms values from abstract concepts to concrete business assets while ensuring they remain authentic and meaningful. By starting with real experiences that matter rather than word selection, you'll help entrepreneurs build truly distinctive businesses aligned with what they genuinely care about.

10 minutes: Guided Reflection & Discussion

Ask: "Think about a time when your work felt deeply meaningful to you - when you felt like what you were doing really mattered. What was happening in that moment?"

Facilitate sharing of these moments, noting common themes on the board.

Follow-up: "What made these experiences meaningful? What conditions or situations created that sense of purpose?"

Connect to Mission & Values:
- Mission is not about grand statements, but about creating the conditions for meaningful experiences
- Values are not abstract words, but the lived priorities that show up in your meaningful moments
- When your business creates these same meaningful conditions for customers, employees and communities, you build authentic connection

Examples to share:
- Patagonia's mission "We're in business to save our home planet" emerged from the founder's meaningful experiences in nature
- Their repair program came from valuing durability and reducing waste, not from selecting "sustainability" from a word list

Ask: "How might creating these meaningful conditions for others also create business advantages?"
Potential answers:
- Customers who share these values become loyal advocates
- Employees find deeper motivation beyond paychecks
- Decision-making becomes clearer and more consistent
- Resource efficiency happens naturally when you focus on what truly matters
```

## Updated Content for Slide 16: Discovering Your Core Values

```
DISCOVERING YOUR CORE VALUES

20 minutes: Facilitated Activity

Introduction: "Instead of selecting values from a list, we'll discover them in your most meaningful experiences."

Step 1: Meaningful Moments (5 min - Individual)
- Write down 2-3 specific moments when your work felt most meaningful
- What was happening? Who was involved? What made it matter?

Step 2: Identify Underlying Values (5 min - Individual)
- For each meaningful moment, ask: "What made this situation important to me?"
- What conditions or qualities were present that created meaning?
- What would someone watching notice you cared about?

Step 3: Connect to Customer Experience (5 min - Individual)
- How might your customers experience similar meaningful moments through your business?
- What conditions can your business create that would matter to them in similar ways?

Step 4: Small Group Sharing (5 min)
- Share your meaningful moments and the values you discovered
- Help each other identify authentic values you might have missed
- Discuss how these values could shape business decisions

Facilitator Notes:
- Authentic values come from lived experience, not abstract words
- The same meaning-creating conditions that matter to you will likely matter to others
- These authentic values will inform both your mission and your unique value proposition
- Values aren't just what you say, but how you make decisions when trade-offs arise
```

## Updated Content for Slide 7: Unique Value Proposition 

```
UNIQUE VALUE PROPOSITION: MEANINGFUL DIFFERENCE

10 minutes: Discussion + Exercise

A value proposition is a promise of meaningful value that your business delivers better than alternatives. It answers: "Why should people choose you?"

Ask: "How do your authentic values create a unique advantage in the market?"
Guide discussion to explore:

1. Intersection of Meaning
   - What meaningful experiences do your customers seek?
   - How do your authentic values help create those experiences?
   - What meaningful difference does your solution make compared to alternatives?

2. Business Advantages
   - Does your values-aligned approach create efficiency advantages?
   - Can your authentic values reduce costs or risks in ways competitors can't?
   - Do shared values with customers create stronger loyalty and reduce marketing costs?

Exercise:
Complete this sentence: "Unlike our competitors, we _____________ because we genuinely value _____________."

Examples to share:
- Patagonia: "Unlike typical outdoor brands, we help you keep using what you already own because we genuinely value reducing environmental impact."
- Warby Parker: "Unlike traditional eyewear companies, we make prescription glasses accessible to more people because we genuinely value equal access to vision care."
```

## Bringing It All Together: Integrated Worksheet

I'd create a single integrated worksheet that walks participants through the full journey from meaning to business value:

```
MEANINGFUL BRAND DEVELOPMENT WORKSHEET

PART 1: MEANINGFUL MOMENTS
Describe 2-3 times when your work felt truly meaningful:
1. ________________________________________________
2. ________________________________________________
3. ________________________________________________

What conditions or qualities made these experiences matter to you?
________________________________________________
________________________________________________

PART 2: AUTHENTIC VALUES
Based on your meaningful experiences, what do you genuinely value?
(Not abstract words, but the specific conditions that create meaning)
1. ________________________________________________
2. ________________________________________________
3. ________________________________________________

PART 3: MISSION STATEMENT
How does your business create these same meaningful conditions for others?
________________________________________________
________________________________________________

PART 4: UNIQUE VALUE PROPOSITION

What meaningful experiences do your customers seek?
________________________________________________

How does your business uniquely deliver these experiences?
________________________________________________

Unlike competitors, we _________________ because we genuinely value _________________.

PART 5: BUSINESS ADVANTAGES
How do your authentic values create business benefits?

Lower costs: _______________________________________
(e.g., reduced marketing costs through word-of-mouth, resource efficiency)

Reduced risks: _____________________________________
(e.g., more loyal customers, more stable supply chain)

Market differentiation: _______________________________
(e.g., clear positioning that's hard for competitors to copy)
```

## Key Integration Points

To maintain the business focus while deepening the values exploration:

1. **Frame values as business assets** - Show how authentic values create tangible business advantages (lower acquisition costs, stronger loyalty, better decision-making)

2. **Connect values to efficiency** - Demonstrate how focusing on what truly matters often leads to resource optimization (eliminating meaningless activities, focusing on essential value)

3. **Link values to risk reduction** - Explain how values alignment creates resilience (loyal customers, motivated employees, clearer decision-making in crises)

4. **Integrate values into market differentiation** - Show how authentic values create hard-to-copy competitive advantages

This approach transforms values from abstract concepts to concrete business assets while ensuring they remain authentic and meaningful. By starting with real experiences that matter rather than word selection, you'll help entrepreneurs build truly distinctive businesses aligned with what they genuinely care about.

Quality: iPhones are great quality. We know this because it is consistently true. I would never buy an iPhone and question the quality of it. It is the same in every box in every country (unless it is a fake product). 
Products and services: Apple is consistent in their products and services as well. They are a technology company. I know that they won’t be coming out with furniture or kitchenware. That would make for a very confusing brand. When creating a brand, make sure you are consistent in the things you offer as well.
Creative elements: Commercials, marketing materials, office layout, website, Facebook, and more! Everything is in line with the same creative elements. There is a consistency with color and font schemes. Logos use and all creative elements are consistent. 
You saw the Apple logo and knew what it was immediately. If someone took another icon of a fruit with a bite in it, many of us will think of Apple. That is a strong brand! 
Message: Your message is consistent across all channels, internally, and externally. Whether it is your commercials, the writing on your packaging, blogs that you write, your company culture, or anything else, your message is clear and consistent. What is the problem you are solving? What does your business do? Make sure those things are clear.

messages.content:
You're right that we need to bridge the gap between meaningful experiences and practical business utility. Let's refine the approach to make it more concrete while maintaining the deeper values exploration.

## Updated Slide 14: Mission & Values

I'd suggest this updated content that connects meaningful experiences directly to business outcomes:

```
MISSION & VALUES: PURPOSE THAT POWERS PERFORMANCE

10 minutes: Guided Reflection & Discussion

Ask: "Think about a time when you solved a problem for someone and it felt genuinely satisfying - beyond just earning money. What was happening and why did it matter to you?"

Facilitate sharing of these moments, noting common themes on the board.

Follow-up questions to connect meaning to business:
- "What specific problem were you solving in that moment?"
- "Why did solving this particular problem matter to you personally?"
- "How did solving this problem create value for the other person?"

Connect to Mission & Values:
- Mission is about the specific problem you're passionate about solving and why it matters
- Values are the principles that guide how you solve these problems in your unique way
- When your business consistently solves problems in alignment with what matters to you, you build authentic connection AND sustainable competitive advantage

Examples to share:
- Patagonia's mission "We're in business to save our home planet" connects their practical products (outdoor gear) with the founder's concern about environmental degradation
- Their repair program isn't just "sustainable" - it solves the real customer problem of gear wearing out while aligning with their value of reducing unnecessary consumption

Ask: "How might solving problems in a way that aligns with what matters to you create business advantages?"
Potential answers:
